The merger is the latest of several recent deals in the consolidating semiconductor business.On Nov. 2, chipmaker Broadcom (AVGO) announced a deal to acquire Brocade Communications Systems (BRCD) for $5.9 billion.On Oct. 27, Qualcomm announced a deal to buy NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) for $39 billion in a transaction that will create the second-largest chipmaker by revenue after Intel (INTC). The Qualcomm-NXP transaction marks the biggest semiconductor deal ever, surpassing Avago Technologies' $37 billion purchase of Broadcom.RELATED:Chip M&A Heats Up With Microsemi-Skyworks, Lattice In Spotlight'Top Picks' Among Chip Stocks: Inphi, Intel, Macom, Nvidia, NXPMacom Leapfrogs Apple-Supplying Chip Rivals With Lasers, Radar

The harsh sell-off of semiconductor stocks on Thursday created a buying opportunity for investors wanting a stake in top chip companies, Mizuho Securities analyst Vijay Rakesh said in a report.Semiconductor stocks fell hard Thursday as investors rotated out of the tech sector and also reacted to reports that Apple (AAPL) is cutting production of its iPhone 7 handsets, Rakesh said."The substantial pullback despite much stronger fundamentals, in our view, creates a buying opportunity," he said in a report. "Semiconductor valuations are back to Feb.-April of 2016."Rakesh recommended buying Broadcom (AVGO), Cypress Semiconductor (CY), Intel (INTC), Micron Technology (MU), Microsemi (MSCC), ON Semiconductor (ON), Qualcomm (QCOM) and Western Digital (WDC)."All have, in our view, significant growth and strong fundamentals ahead," he said.IBD'S TAKE: The IBD 50 list of top growth stocks includes six chip companies, such as Microsemi and Nvidia. The IBD 50 is one of many proprietary stock analysis tools for investors to consult on Investors.com.Semiconductor stocks are attractive "given the strong earnings growth, cost synergies, strong industrial, automotive, defense/aerospace, and continued synergistic M&A driven also by a better regulatory environment," Rakesh said.Rakesh's eight stock picks all dropped Thursday, but they all gained some ground on the stock market today.In his report, Rakesh also listed graphics chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) as a buy, but said its steep valuation could give investors pause. Nvidia also edged higher Friday.Meanwhile, Needham analyst Rajvindra Gill reiterated his buy rating on audio chipmaker Cirrus Logic (CRUS) with a price target of 65. He said Cirrus was pushed down on "noise" about iPhone 7 sales."We remain bullish on CRUS as we see several vectors of growth, including further penetration of digital and ultimately ANC (active noise cancellation) headsets (beginning in Q1 2017) in the Android and accessory markets, a better iPhone 8 unit cycle, and expansion in the audio amplifier market," Gill said.Cirrus Logic rose 1.6% to 50.10 on Friday, but fell nearly 13% for the week.RELATED:Demand 'Sedate' For Apple iPhone 7, 'Robust' For iPhone 7 PlusGoPro Chip Supplier Ambarella Down On Weak Q4 Guidance

Netflix (NFLX), Lockheed Martin (LMT) and IBM (IBM) were upgraded to buy Thursday, while Taser International (TASR) had its price target raised, and Qualcomm (QCOM) was downgraded.The streaming video giant was upgraded to buy with a price target of 151 by Loop Capital. Netflix's stock is near its record high, but concerns over costs and plans for 1,000 hours of original content are prompting a new question: Should investors still view the company as a tech disrupter shaking up Big Media, or has its seduction by Hollywood left it unable to still act like a nimble tech startup?Netflix initially rose higher but reversed to close down 5.5% at 115.42 in the stock market today as investors dumped many big-cap techs.RELATED:Apple, FANG Stocks Aren't Joining Trump RallyThe Pentagon contractor was upgraded to a buy from hold with a price target of 275 by Deutsche Bank. The Defense Department finalized a $6.1 billion contract with Lockheed Martin last week for the ninth batch of F-35 stealth fighters, though both sides remain in a dispute about pricing.Lockheed Martin stock rose 1.5% at 257.22, after rallying 6% Wednesday on expectations that a Trump administration would boost military spending.Big Blue was upgraded to a buy with a price target of 185 by Bank of America. The artificial intelligence of IBM's Watson will be used to make millions of General Motors (GM) cars smarter through a new partnership between the automaker and tech giant, the companies said Wednesday.IBM rallied 3.5% to finish at 160.22.Qualcomm was downgraded to equal weight from overweight with a price target of 65 by Morgan Stanley. Qualcomm reported Q3 earnings last week that beat on the top and bottom lines. Its Q4 outlook was largely below views. The outlook may give some indication of the fallout from Samsung's Note 7 fiasco, as well as the strength of demand for the Apple iPhone 7.Qualcomm last week announced plans to buy NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) for $39 billion.Qualcomm stock briefly rose but has reversed to end down 2.3% to 66.31.Taser had its price target raised to 35 from 33 by Craig Hallum. Taser reported third-quarter earnings late Wednesday that beat estimates. The company, which provides stun-weaponry, body cameras and online information storage systems, has over the years landed sales deals with a variety of law enforcement agencies in the U.S. and abroad.Shares jumped 13% to close at 26.82, retaking the 50-day line.

One day ahead of another historic U.S. presidential election, the relief rally by the stocks in the wake of an ended FBI investigation over Hillary Clinton's emails finished strong Monday. Meanwhile, Apple (AAPL) lagged the major indexes, yet the heavily influential stock is now making a second attempt to make a significant move past a 110.33 cup-with-handle buy point.Apple closed the day up 1.4% to 110.44. After its Sept. 14 initial breakout, shares in the largest company on the U.S. exchanges by market cap rallied as much as 7.6% before backtracking along with the general market.Turnover in Apple finished 15% below average, a slight disappointment, but it appeared to rise from Friday's quiet session.On the dawn of a pivotal U.S. presidential election, the Nasdaq composite led the way, closing ahead nearly 2.4% and wiping away last week's 2% loss. The S&P 500 wasn't far behind, rising 2.2%.A wide range of industry groups tracked by IBD raced 3% higher or more, including jewelry retail, data storage, managed health insurers, hospitals, biotech, travel booking, security software and trucking. Gold and silver miners were the only stocks seeing deep losses. Volume was running moderately lower on both main exchanges vs. the same time Friday, according to preliminary data.Small caps also roared higher, with the Russell 2000 rebounding 2.5% and the S&P SmallCap 600 rising 2.4%.The Dow Jones industrials rallied 2.1%, their biggest gain since late January. Financials helped the cause, particularly Wall Street banks including JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS).  The former roared 3.1% higher to 69.88, and now has rallied 7% past a 65.08 cup with handle entry, and is thus extended in price. Don't chase stocks more than 5% past the proper buy point.Goldman jumped more than 3% to 181.48 and is now slightly extended: 5.2% past a 172.52 entry in a bottoming base pattern.Breakouts were relatively scarce Monday, but Gigamon (GIMO) surged 7% to 57.88, clearing a 56.48 buy point in heavy volume and clearing a flat-base-like consolidation.The drop within the new base was 14%, meeting the 15% limit for flat-base patterns. The data security play also rebounded nicely back above the 50-day line on Oct. 28, triggering a new buy point near 50. Gigamon is now extended from that entry.Returning to Apple, the consumer tech play is trying to reclaim its key 50-day moving average after sliding below it last week. However, other technical gauges point to generally improved strength in the megacap tech. The RS Rating of 70, as seen in IBD Stock Checkup, is a huge lift from 26 eight weeks ago. The 70 rating means Apple is now outperforming 70% of all companies in IBD's database over the past 12 months.IBD Stock Checkup also shows the up/down volume ratio rising to a neutral 1.0. A ratio of more than 1.0 means that a stock has seen more volume on up days in price vs. down days over the past 50 trading sessions. Apple's Accumulation/Distribution Rating of B- implies rising share accumulation by mutual funds, hedge funds, pensions and the like.Wall Street still expects Apple to post its smallest decline in earnings in its December-ending fiscal first quarter, down less than 2% to $3.22 a share. The highest estimate among 36 analysts is $3.77, up 15%. Revenue is seen edging up 2% to $77.1 billion, which would end a three-quarter drought of falling sales.While research firm KGI Securities said iPhone shipments are likely to drop in the first half of 2017, primarily due to weak demand in China,  suppliers of key components for Apple iPhones brushed off such news and rallied.Broadcom (AVGO), an IBD Leaderboard name, gained 2.8% to 176.96, climbing past a 176 aggressive entry within a flat base. The stock's RS line continues to rise, meaning it's outpacing the performance of the S&P 500. The RS line is painted in blue in IBD charts.Qualcomm (QCOM) gapped up 2.6% to 68.46, keeping above its 50-day line; its solid uptrend is intact. The stock initially broke out of a bottoming cup pattern at 56.37 in July.RELATED:What Is The Bottoming Base Pattern?When Did Apple Break Out?Will The Stock Market Rise More If Hillary Wins, Or Donald Wins?

Stocks forfeited modest gains during an afternoon sell-off Friday, leaving the indexes mildly in the red by day's end. Small caps, however, bucked the decline.Volume edged slightly lower on both exchanges, according to preliminary data, ahead of Tuesday's pivotal presidential election. As the latest Investor's Corner column notes, in recent decades the average gain during Democratic presidencies has outweighed Republican ones.The Nasdaq composite let an intraday gain of nearly 0.5% slide back into a 0.2% loss; while negative reversals are not constructive for the bulls, the overall intraday range was not that wide.Meanwhile, Apple (AAPL) squandered early gains to finish 0.9% lower at 108.84, less than 2 points below its 110.33 proper entry point in a cup-with-handle pattern.It's now spent four sessions on the south side of its 50-day moving average. That's not a lot of time, but you'd like to see a leading stock trading above the 50-day line when it's trying to break out.The S&P 500 lost slightly less than 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrials fell slightly more than 0.2%. But the Russell 2000 gained nearly 0.6%, cutting its weekly loss to 2%.For the week, the Nasdaq fell 2.8%, its second worst weekly drop in 2016. The tech-rich composite slumped 5.4% in the week ended Feb. 5.The S&P 500 lost 1.9% for the week, sinking in four of the past five weeks. The large-cap benchmark is now challenging support at its 40-week moving average (please see a weekly chart; the 40-week line roughly mimics the 200-day line on a daily chart).The general market on Friday encountered seesaw trading all day, following a smaller-than-expected increase in October U.S. payrolls. But the Labor Department also sharply revised higher job gains in the prior two months by an additional 44,000 jobs. Plus, economists heralded the 10-cent hike in average wages, noting that gives the Federal Reserve more reason to raise interest rates during its final meeting of the year (Dec. 13-14).Other big-cap techs also fell for the week, including Qualcomm (QCOM) (down 2.4%), Activision Blizzard (ATVI) (down 3.7%) and Intel (INTC) (down 3.1%).Qualcomm held steady at its 10-week moving average. The wireless chip technology giant plans to buy NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) to broaden its product library. Activision reported solid Q3 results (EPS up 152%, sales up 58%) but still fell below its 10-week line. Intel is trying to stop a slide through its longer-term 40-week moving average.Tesla Motors (TSLA) rose more 1.7% to 190.56, ending a vicious five-day slide. Yet since losing buying support at the 50-day moving average in late August, the electric vehicle leader has failed twice in rising back above the key intermediate trend line.As noted in past Stock Market Today columns, the former big winner of 2013 likely needs a lot more time before investors pile back into the stock and drive it to a level where it could potentially break out.Funds sponsorship in Tesla is checkered, as the number of mutual and hedge funds owning shares has declined from 1,048 at the end of 2015 to 1,017 at the end of the third quarter this year, but total shares owned have increased from 52.8 million to 55.7 million.Elsewhere in the market, Monster Beverage (MNST) dropped as much as 10% early before cutting its loss to less than 4% and ending at 135.23. Volume surged by seven times its 50-day average after the energy drink marketer reported disappointing Q3 adjusted earnings of 99 cents a share, up 18% but nearly 12% below Wall Street's consensus view.Monster's third-quarter sales rose 4% to $788 million, the smallest increase in five quarters. The stock's IBD Composite Rating on Stock Checkup has fallen to a middling 75 out of a maximum 99.RELATED:What Is The Bottoming Base Chart Pattern, And How Do Investors Profit From It?When Did Apple Break Out This Year?How Will The Stock Market Do After The Nov. 8 Presidential Election?Where Can I Learn All Of IBD's Key Sell Rules For Stocks?

Apple (AAPL) chip suppliers Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) and Qorvo (QRVO) diverged after they posted September-quarter financial results late Thursday. Skyworks delivered a beat-and-raise report, while Qorvo disappointed with guidance and gave mixed fiscal second-quarter results.Skyworks rose 0.5% to 75.07 on the stock market today, while Qorvo fell 10% to 51.08 and hit a five-month low.Skyworks Solutions earned $1.47 a share excluding items, down 3% year over year, on sales of $835.4 million, down 5%, in its fiscal Q4. Analysts were modeling Skyworks to earn $1.43 a share on sales of $831.3 million.The Woburn, Mass.-based company guided to $1.58 EPS and $902 million in sales for the December quarter, vs. Wall Street's targets of $1.56 EPS and $893 million in sales.IBD'S TAKE: Skyworks has an IBD Composite Rating of 92, but it ranks No. 12 out of 40 stocks in IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Manufacturing industry group. To see which companies lead the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.Skyworks stock earned price-target hikes from Cowen, Craig Hallum and Needham. Cowen maintained its buy rating and upped its price target to 80 from 72. Craig Hallum reiterated its buy rating and raised its PT to 90 from 85. Needham stuck with its buy rating and increased its price target to 84 from 73.Qorvo earned $1.29 a share excluding items, up 6%, on sales of $864.7 million, up 22%, in its fiscal Q2. Analysts were looking for adjusted EPS of $1.41 on sales of $834.8 million.Qorvo guided to $1.25 EPS and $820 million in sales, well short of Wall Street's target of $1.45 EPS and $845 million in sales.Greensboro, N.C.-based Qorvo has been plagued by manufacturing yield issues, Oppenheimer analyst Rick Schafer said in a research report.Bank of America Merrill Lynch downgraded Qorvo to underperform from buy after the earnings news.Cowen reiterated its market perform rating on Qorvo, but cut its price target to 53 from 65.Mergers and acquisitions in the semiconductor industry have overshadowed earnings reports from chip firms this earnings season.Mobile chip maker Qualcomm (QCOM), which plans to buy NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), on Wednesday posted fiscal Q4 results that beat Wall Street's expectations.Qualcomm said its earnings per share excluding items rose 41% to $1.28 while sales rose 13% to $6.17 billion. Analysts were expecting EPS of $1.13 on sales of $5.84 billion.On Thursday, shares of chipmaker Microsemi (MSCC) soared on a report that fellow mixed-signal-chip expert Skyworks has approached the company about a potential acquisition.Skyworks is benefiting from growing content wins in mobile phones. Apple accounts for about 40% of its revenue, Samsung 15% and Chinese vendors 20%, Schafer said."Skyworks' growth trajectory remains on track to benefit from increasing demands for integrated RF/analog solutions," Schafer said. He rates Skyworks stock as outperform with a price target of 100.Cowen analyst Timothy Arcuri said Skyworks' results and guidance were "solid, if not spectacular, and execution remains unassailable."RELATED:Chip M&A Heats Up With Microsemi-Skyworks, Lattice In Spotlight

Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) is expected to report a 55% profit gain for the third quarter Wednesday morning. Here's what to look for from the operator of the WeChat mobile messaging app.Estimates: Tencent is expected to report a net profit of 11.51 billion yuan ($1.68 billion) from 7.45 billion yuan a year earlier. Revenue likely rose 47% to 39.06 billion yuan.Stock: Tencent rose 2.9% to 25.29 on the stock market today after hitting a three-month low on Monday. Tencent is listed in Hong Kong and trades over the counter in the U.S.Online games still accounts for nearly half of Tencent's revenue, though it faces stiff competition in China from mobile games specialist NetEase (NTES) and others. Tencent recently agreed to buy Supercell, creator of "Clash of Clans" and other hot mobile games. It also owns LA-based Riot Games, creator of the popular "League Of Legends" massively multiplayer online game.IBD'S TAKE: Want to invest in China's huge online growth but don't know which stock to choose? Check out these China and Asian tech ETFs.Advertising is a growing share of Tencent's sales. Tencent relies far less on ad revenue than Facebook (FB), so analysts see room from growth.Tencent also has been taking market share in mobile payments from Alipay, the financial arm of archrival Alibaba (BABA), thanks to the strength of WeChat and its WeChatPay.(Tencent also recently has overtaken Alibaba in terms of market cap, $239 billion to $227.5 billion, respectively).Facebook has been trying to copy some of the features of WeChat in its WhatApp and Facebook Messenger apps. But in China many people can do all their communication and shopping on the WeChat app while in the U.S. users have dozens of apps.In other news, Tencent and Qualcomm (QCOM) on Tuesday announced a "strategic relationship ... to identify and create leading immersive mobile user experiences in gaming and entertainment."Tencent has a web of alliances and strategic stakes. It owns roughly 20% of e-commerce giant JD.com (JD), which reported earnings Tuesday morning. JD topped profit views and gave strong guidance for Q4. JD shares shot up 11.4% to 26.41 Tuesday, retaking its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.RELATED:JD.com Q3 Earnings Top Views; Exploring Sale Of Financial UnitAlibaba Growth Booms On Cloud Computing, But Stock ReversesNetEase Reveals $1 Billion Share Buyback Plan

Mergers and acquisitions in the chip sector are heating up following a couple of recent big deals.On Thursday, shares of chipmaker Microsemi (MSCC) soared on a report that fellow mixed-signal-chip expert Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) has approached the company about a potential acquisition.Microsemi stock was up 15.5%, above 48, in afternoon trading after earlier in the day hitting an all-time high of 50. Skyworks was up a fraction, below 76.Also Thursday, newly formed private equity firm Canyon Bridge Capital Partners signed an agreement to buy programmable-chip maker Lattice Semiconductor (LSCC) for $1.3 billion, or $8.30 a share.Lattice stock was up over 18%, near 7.55, in afternoon trading on the stock market today. It ended the day Wednesday at 6.37, up 1%."We believe this acquisition will be noticed across the industry as it may potentially be the beginning of increased private equity involvement in semiconductor consolidation trends (especially in the small- to midcap space)," William Blair analyst Anil Doradla said in a report.IBD'S TAKE: Chip stocks are hot right now. IBD's fabless semiconductor industry group is ranked No. 4 out of 197 groups, while IBD's semiconductor manufacturing group is ranked No. 8. To see the best stocks in IBD's 33 sectors, check out IBD's Sector Leaders stock list.Susquehanna Financial Group analyst Christopher Rolland listed Lattice as his No. 2 takeout play in a report last Friday on possible M&A candidates. He listed Microsemi as his No. 3 pick. His No. 1 pick is Marvell Technology Group (MRVL).The latest chip M&A talk comes after two big semiconductor deals.On Wednesday, chipmaker Broadcom (AVGO) announced a deal to acquire Brocade Communications Systems (BRCD) for $5.9 billion.On Oct. 27, Qualcomm (QCOM) announced a deal to buy NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) for $39 billion in a transaction that will create the second largest chipmaker by revenue after Intel (INTC).The Qualcomm-NXP transaction marks the biggest semiconductor deal ever, surpassing Avago Technologies' $37 billion purchase of Broadcom.RELATED:Broadcom To Buy Brocade For $5.9 Billion, Reaffirms Q4 GuidanceQualcomm Inks Deal To Buy NXP For $39 Billion

Facebook (FB), Qualcomm (QCOM), Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) and Parsley Energy (PE) topped forecasts late Wednesday, while Fitbit (FIT) shares collapsed on disastrous guidance Continental Resources (CLR) ramped up its drilling and fracking plans.Estimates: Adjusted Q3 EPS up 70% to 97 cents, ending four straight quarters of accelerating growth. Revenue up 54% to $6.92 billion.Results: EPS of $1.09 on revenue of $7.01 billion. Monthly active users rose 16% to 1.79 billion. Mobile monthly active users climbed 20% to 1.66 billion. Mobile ad revenue was 84% of the total, up from 78%.Stock: Shares were up 0.4% late after closing down 1.8% to 127.17 on the stock market today, below their 50-day average for the first time since July. The stock has been unable to get back above a 132.08 buy point in recent sessions and on Tuesday undercut an earlier entry point of 128.43 from a prior consolidation.The world's largest social network is grabbing a bigger share of online and total ad dollars while also expanding further into e-commerce.Estimates: Q3 EPS down 21% to 19 cents, with sales up 24% to $506.93 million.Results: EPS of 19 cents on revenue of $503.8 million.Outlook: Q4 EPS of 14-18 cents, vs. consensus of 75 cents, on revenue of $725 million-$750 million, below views for $985 million.Stock: Shares sank 30% after hours. Since plunging from its August 2015 peak to its June 2016 low, the stock has remained below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Fitbit's results and outlook will provide clues into the wearables market ahead of the holiday season as competition heats up vs. the Apple (AAPL) Watch and wearables from Garmin (GRMN) and others.Estimates: Fiscal Q4 EPS up 24% to $1.13; revenue up 1% to $5.842 billion.Results: Adjusted EPS of $1.28 on revenue of $6.18 billion.Outlook: Q1 EPS of $1.12-$1.22, largely below views of $1.22, on revenue of $5.7 billion-$6.5 billion, in line with consensus for $6.15 billion.Stock: Shares edged down 0.1% late.The outlook may give some indication of the fallout from Samsung's Note 7 fiasco, as well as the strength of demand for the Apple iPhone 7. Qualcomm last week announced plans to buy NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) for $39 billion.Estimates: Q3 per-share loss to widen to 15 cents from 12 cents, as revenue falls 11.4% to $556.7 million.Results: Per-share loss of 30 cents on revenue of $526.2 million.Outlook: Full-year production now seen at 215,000-220,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, an increase of 5,000 from the low end of previous guidance given in August.Continental plans to increase its gross operated well completions this year by 32, and plans to increase stimulation crews in North Dakota to four from two by the end of the year.Stock: Shares dropped 4% late after finishing down 4% as a surge in U.S. crude stockpiles sent futures lower.Estimates: Q3 to swing to a profit of 2 cents a share from a loss of 8 cents a share, with revenue more than doubling to $129.2 million.Results: Adjusted EPS of 3 cents on revenue of $132.7 million. Net production nearly doubled to 43,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day.Outlook: Full-year production now seen at 37,000-39,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up from 36,000-38,000 BOE. Parsley is adding 450 net horizontal drilling locations to its Midland Basin inventory.Stock: Shares fell 2%, dropping further below their 50-day average.The Permian Basin-focused producer is in the middle of the hottest U.S. shale formation, where oil can be extracted profitably even at lower prices.Estimates: Fiscal Q2 EPS down 3.3% to 29 cents as revenue climbs 10% to $402.6 million.Results: EPS of 45 cents on revenue of $420.2 million on bookings of $452.8 million.Outlook: Q3 EPS of 30-40 cents, below views for $1.04, on revenue of $475 million-$525 million, also below consensus for $649.7 million. Take-Two sees Q3 bookings of $650 million-$700 million.Stock: Shares jumped 4.6% in extended trade.The video game publisher follows Electronic Arts' (EA) strong results Tuesday and comes ahead of Activision Blizzard's (ATVI) report Thursday.

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSM) early Thursday reported better-than-expected third-quarter sales and earnings and raised its guidance for the current quarter as it continues to benefit from supplying chips for Apple's (AAPL) new iPhone 7.TSMC earned 60 cents a share, up 36% year over year and better than the 57 cents predicted by analysts. It was a return to earnings growth for the company after four straight quarters of decline.IBD'S TAKE: TSMC has an IBD Composite Rating of 89, meaning it has outperformed 89% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. But it is ranked No. 10 out of 39 companies on IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Manufacturing industry group. To see which companies lead the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.TSMC said sales rose 29% to $8.3 billion.The semiconductor foundry provided December-quarter sales guidance that was 5% higher than consensus estimates. TSMC executives said the higher view was based on better high-end smartphone demand as well as strength in China and emerging markets."We believe Apple iPhone 7 shipments are one of the main drivers to TSM's guidance, as the Taiwanese foundry makes Apple's A10 application processors, as well as the baseband modems sold by both Qualcomm (QCOM) and Intel (INTC)," BMO Capital Markets analyst Tim Long said in a research report. "We view this data point as another sign that sales for the iPhone 7 and 7 Plus are strong."Taiwan Semi's U.S. stock, however, closed down 2.6% at 30.53 on the stock market today, after shares touched an all-time high of 31.48 on Monday. TSMC stock is well extended from a June breakout at 26.68.For Q4, Taiwan Semi sees strong demand continuing, especially for chips with 16-nanometer and 28-nm fabrication nodes, Cowen said in a report.TSMC expects to start 10-nm wafer production this quarter, with the first wave of chip customers coming from the high-end smartphone sector. It is on track for 7-nm development as well, with risk production starting Q1 2017. Nanometers basically refers to the width of the circuitry etching on silicon, so the smaller the number the more powerful the chip.RELATED:Brooks Automation, MKS Instruments Rated Chip-Gear BuysQualcomm Among Chipmakers Hurt By Galaxy Note 7 Demise

Samsung Electronics said that pulling the Note 7 smartphone will reduce operating profit by mid-three trillion won ($3 billion) in the fourth quarter and the first quarter of 2017.Samsung, in a statement issued Friday local time but Thursday night in New York, expects that ending the sale and production of the Note 7 due to overheating problems will cut profit by 2 trillion won in Q4 and 1 trillion in Q1 2017. Samsung had already forecast a $2.3 billion hit to Q3 operating earnings.The Korean electronics giant will focus on selling more Galaxy 7 smartphone line.Samsung shares have fallen sharply this week. But it's good news for Apple (AAPL), which could sell another 15 million iPhone 7 handsets according to some forecasts.IBD'S TAKE: The iPhone already is cool with U.S. teens, with 74% owning an Apple smartphone vs. 67% a year earlier, according to Piper Jaffray.  Here's more on Apple, GoPro, FitBit and more in Piper Jaffray's teen buying survey.Apple shares fell 0.3% on the stock market today, but are still up 2.6% so far this week, hitting a 2016 high. That compares to a 1.5% drop for the Nasdaq so far this week.Meanwhile, Samsung's woes could have a modestly negative impact on some wireless chipmakers, such as Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM), Qualcomm (QCOM) and Qorvo (QRVO).RELATED:Apple Stock Gains On Samsung Battery Pains; iPhone Loses RivalQualcomm Among Chipmakers Hurt By Galaxy Note 7 Demise

Mobile chipmaker Qualcomm (QCOM) got an upgrade Monday on expectations that its acquisition of NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) will expand markets, open new channels and boost earnings.Nomura analyst Romit Shah upgraded Qualcomm stock to buy from neutral and raised his price target to 80 from 55.Qualcomm stock rose 0.47% to 68.72 in the stock market today.Qualcomm on Thursday announced a deal to buy NXP Semiconductors for $39 billion in a transaction that will create the second-largest chipmaker by revenue after Intel (INTC).IBD'S TAKE: The semiconductor sector is hot. The IBD 50 list of top performers includes seven chip stocks, though Qualcomm and NXP are not among them. Learn more about why the "Semiconductor Sector Still Offers Plenty Of Leadership."An acquisition of NXP would help Qualcomm diversify beyond its leadership position in mobile-phone chips. Qualcomm said the acquisition will expand its footprint into key growth markets, including automotive, the Internet of Things, security and networking. It says adding NXP will expand its total addressable market by about 40%, to $138 billion, in 2020.The combined company is expected to have annual revenue of more than $30 billion."NXP will add a ton of scale, expand the total addressable market and open new channels for Snapdragon," Qualcomm's core microprocessor, Shah wrote in his research note. "We conservatively estimate that NXP will boost earnings, inclusive of stock compensation expense, by 30% to $6 a share in 2018."RELATED:Qualcomm Among Chipmakers Hurt By Galaxy Note 7 DemiseAnalysts Bullish On Possible Qualcomm-NXP Merger

Here's your Investing Action Plan: What you need to know as an investor for Wednesday. Internet giants Facebook (FB) and Alibaba Group (BABA) headline another busy day for earnings. Fitbit's (FIT) and Qualcomm's (QCOM) reports should provide some insight into Apple (AAPL) product demand for the holiday season. Facebook and Apple nearly undercut buy points cleared weeks ago, while Alibaba is…

Analysts changed their minds on a number of stocks Monday, including Nike (NKE), Macy's (M), Nordstrom (JWN) and Qualcomm (QCOM). Acacia Communications (ACIA) and new issue Coupa Software (COUP) both received fresh attention as well.Bank of America downgraded the athletic apparel giant to underperform from neutral, citing competition from Under Armour (UA) and Adidas abroad, according to Seeking Alpha.Shares fell 3.5% to 50.18 at the close on the stock market today, falling to their lowest level since August 2015.Deutsche Bank handed Macy's an upgrade to buy but cut Nordstrom's rating to hold on Monday. Analysts at the bank believe Macy's can increase profit margins through the end of next year, according to CNBC, but are concerned about Nordstrom's valuation.Department store stocks, as well as shares of many specialty retailers, have been choppy amid ongoing concerns about the health of the retail environment.Macy's shares rose 2.6% to 36.49 while Nordstrom fell 1.3% to 52.The chipmaker was upgraded to buy by Nomura, which cited benefits from its recently announced acquisition of NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) -- in particular a 30% per-share profit boost to $6 in 2018, an accretion that will be "too substantial for investors to ignore," according to the note acquired by StreetInsider.Nomura raised its Qualcomm price target to 80 from 55.Qualcomm rose 0.5% to close at 68.72.William Blair initiated coverage on the fiber optic stock, giving it an outperform rating.Shares of the May IPO are still well above their IPO price of 23 a share but are downtrending from a 128.73 peak in September and have remained below their 50-day line since early October.Acacia dropped 2.2% to 69.69 at the close.Wall Street initiated coverage on the software company, which started trading on Oct. 6, with a neutral rating from JPMorgan, equal weight from both Barclays and Morgan Stanley, plus outperforms from RBC Capital Markets and JMP Securities.Shares haven't yet retaken their first-day high of 41.61 but remain well above their 18 new issue price.Coupa fell 1.3% to close at 25.RELATED:Qualcomm Inks Deal To Buy NXP For $39 BillionAcacia Communications Hammered On Customer ZTE's Sales MissCoupa Software Doubles, Giving Another Big Boost To IPO Market

Growth-stock funds have outperformed their blend and value counterparts in the past 10 years. But the reverse is true for this year, with the average value fund up nearly 8%, the average blend fund up nearly 6% and the average growth fund up 3%.Among the growth funds that have kept pace with value funds this year is Parnassus Endeavor Fund (PARWX). The large-cap growth fund is up 12% this year. Its recent top holdings include Applied Materials (AMAT), up 56% this year, Qualcomm (QCOM) up 43% and Micron Technology (MU) up 24%.Holdings that haven't done as well include Gilead Sciences (GILD), down 24% this year, and generic-drug maker Perrigo (PRGO) down 37%.The $1.9 billion fund has been managed by Jerome Dodson since 2005.The fund seeks to buy high-quality companies that it can hold long-term. It seeks to keep about 30 companies in its portfolio, giving significant weightings to most. It has a turnover rate of 63%.Parnassus Endeavor has an environmental, social and governance (ESG) component, as holdings must offer outstanding workplaces and not be involved with oil and other fossil fuels.In his fund commentary for Q3, written in early October, Dodson said the market looked fairly valued. A decline in the number of attractive stocks helps explain why cash in the fund had built up to over 15%, way above average for stock funds. It's also way above his goal for 5% cash."Although I would like to put some of the cash to work, I won't invest just for the sake of reducing our cash position," he said. "There has to be a good idea to inspire an investment, and that means a good company trading at a very attractive price. This strategy has served us well over the years, as evidenced by our strong returns, so I'm not tempted to change our policy and lower the fund's standards just to reduce our cash balance."Strong inflow to the fund from investors attracted by its strong performance has contributed to the cash build. Dodson encourages investors stay the course. "Keep those investments coming in! At some point, I'll figure out what to do with the money," he said.Dodson professed a lack of deep concern for the likely path for interest rates."While the immediate reaction to an interest-rate increase will probably be a drop in the stock market, longer‐term, a gradual and reasonable increase in rates will probably not depress the market for very long," he said in his commentary."Rising interest rates usually mean the economy is doing better, so corporations are doing better and stocks find a way to move higher," he continued. "If interest rates move higher late this year or early next year, the initial reaction may be a stock market swoon. If this happens, and stocks go down to more attractive valuations, it may provide us with an opportunity to put some of that idle cash to work."RELATED:Parnassus' Dodson Wins With Hot Tech Stocks That Pass ESG ScreensThis Is What Fidelity Trend Likes About Apple, Amazon And AlphabetWhy A Top Columbia Fund Likes These Stock LeadersChinese, Other Foreign Stocks Drove Top Q3 Mutual Fund Performance

Qualcomm (QCOM) on Thursday announced a deal to buy NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) for $39 billion in a transaction that will create the second largest chipmaker by revenue after Intel (INTC).Qualcomm will pay $110 a share for the Dutch chipmaker, a 34% premium to where NXP stock was trading before news of the acquisition first leaked on Sept. 29. NXP ended Wednesday at 98.66. Including debt, the deal is worth $47 billion.Qualcomm stock rose 2.8% to 70.09 on the stock market today. NXP Semiconductors closed 0.4% higher at 99.08.Mobile-communications chipmaker Qualcomm said the acquisition will expand its footprint into key growth markets, including automotive, Internet of Things, security and networking. It also will expand its total addressable market by about 40% to $138 billion in 2020.IBD'S TAKE: Qualcomm and NXP are members of IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group, which currently ranks No. 7 out of 197 groups. But neither are in the top five companies in the group. To see which stocks are leading the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.NXP is a leading semiconductor systems supplier to the automotive industry, with positions in infotainment, networking and safety systems. Its products are designed into 14 of the top 15 infotainment system customers in 2016.The combined company is expected to have annual revenue of more than $30 billion.Qualcomm expects the transaction to be significantly accretive to non-GAAP earnings per share immediately upon close. It sees $500 million of annualized run-rate cost synergies within two years after the transaction closes.San Diego-based Qualcomm will pay for NXP with offshore cash and new debt. It expects the deal to close by the end of 2017."The NXP acquisition accelerates our strategy to extend our leading mobile technology into robust new opportunities, where we will be well positioned to lead by delivering integrated semiconductor solutions at scale," Qualcomm CEO Steve Mollenkopf said in a statement.The Qualcomm-NXP transaction marks the biggest semiconductor deal ever, surpassing Avago Technologies' $37 billion purchase of Broadcom (AVGO).

Stocks resumed their stiff selling in the first hour of trading Thursday following a sharper drop in weekly jobless claims than expected. The further evidence of a strengthening economy likely boosts the chance of a nominal hike in interest rates in December, and investors are deciding to take a more defensive stance this week. Wall Street was also spooked by weak export data out of China.The Nasdaq composite fell 1.3%, hurt by sharp drops in big-cap techs, before rebounding a bit. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrials were both down around 0.8% to 0.9%. Small caps also saw fierce selling. The S&P SmallCap 600 and the Russell 2000 both sank, dropping more than 1.3% initially before shaving their losses a tad.The Dow utility average rallied more than 0.5%. It's a relatively weak rebound, though, considering that in the prior two weeks the index lost more than a combined 7% in value and barreled below both its 10-week and 40-week moving averages (please see a weekly chart at Marketsmith.com).The Nasdaq is showing further weakness after reversing from small gains and closing slightly below its 50-day moving average on Wednesday. On Tuesday, IBD changed the current outlook for the market to "uptrend under pressure" due to an escalation in heavy institutional selling in recent weeks.On Monday, the Nasdaq slid 1.5% in higher volume, a classic distribution day in which fund managers actively took profits. The Nasdaq had climbed as much as 16% since hitting a near-term bottom of 4574 on June 27. Three sessions later, it posted a rare Day 3 follow-through, signaling a potential market bottom was in place.Qualcomm (QCOM), the wireless chip play, is down 2.6% to 64.34 as shares continue to pull back following a 9% rally in the last week of September. Chip and wireless-related stocks are cooling off after poor quarterly results coming from wireless gear supplier Ericsson (ERIC) on Wednesday.See if Qualcomm can continue to hold its recent new trend of higher highs and higher lows. On July 22, the stock broke out of a bottoming base and leapt past a 56.37 buy point in a super-long saucer with handle structure in big volume. The strong move also enabled Qualcomm to shatter a long-term downtrend. The catalyst: a 17% jump in earnings per share, breaking a four-quarter streak of falling profit, on a 4% lift in revenue.In mid-September, shares then made a successful rebound off the 50-day moving average near 60, providing a second opportunity to scoop up shares.Apple (AAPL) is posting its first decline after a seven-session run that has taken shares up as much as 7.6% above a new 110.33 cup-with-handle buy point. Shares eased 1% to 116.11, still extended past that proper entry.On the upside, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) gapped up at the open and rose more than 6% to 254.90 in fast turnover following bullish earnings guidance. The cosmetics and beauty products retailer also sees 20%+ EPS growth through 2019.Ulta has been one of the best performing consumer products and retailing stocks in recent years. Shares have now taken back the 10-week moving average and are now fashioning the right side of a potential new base.Ulta's latest breakout came in March with a breakaway gap past a 188.58 pivot point. Currently, the stock boasts a solid 94 Composite Rating from IBD Stock Checkup, which means its combination of earnings and sales fundamentals, price action and institutional sponsorship is superior to 94% of all publicly traded companies in IBD's database.RELATED:What Is A Bottoming Base Chart Pattern?Ulta Sees Robust Profit Growth Through 2019Why Apple Shares Are Still Crisp After Breaking Out

It was a huge week for earnings. Apple (AAPL), Amazon (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOGL) were A-list headliners, but a slew of industrials, medicals, restaurants and more also reported. Tesla Motors (TSLA) reported a surprise profit, while Qualcomm (QCOM) will buy NXP Semiconductors (NXPI).The Nasdaq fell 1.3% for the week, with Amazon's miss and Apple's modest beat failing to impress. The tech-heavy index dropped below its 50-day line after retaking that level last week. The S&P 500 sank 0.7%, while the Dow rose 0.1%. Bonds continued to fall around the world, pushing the 10-year Treasury yield to multimonth highs.In the September quarter, Apple earned $1.67 a share, down 15% year over year, on sales of $46.85 billion, down 9%. Analysts expected Apple to earn $1.66 a share on sales of $46.94 billion. For the holiday quarter, Apple guided Wall Street higher on revenue, but its profit margin outlook came up short. Apple also unveiled new MacBook Pro notebook computers, which feature a touch-screen strip for application commands and shortcuts that replaces the function keys. Apple fell 2.5% for the week, but remains above its 50-day line.Amazon reported Q3 earnings of 52 cents a share, a big gain but well short of estimates for 78 cents. The e-commerce giant plowed money into its Amazon Web Services cloud computing unit, along with a big expansion of fulfillment centers heading into the holiday season. Revenue rose 29% to $32.7 billion, meeting views. AWS was among the bright spots in the earnings report as revenue rose 55% year over year to $3.23 billion, beating the consensus. Q4 revenue guidance also lagged. Amazon shares fell 5.2% Friday, closing below its 50-day line for the first time in months.Q3 earnings per share minus items rose 23% to $9.06 while total revenue climbed 20% to $22.45 billion vs. consensus estimates of $8.60 and $22.05 billion. Google-parent Alphabet signaled higher investments in its  cloud computing business and higher Q4 marketing costs tied to the September launch of Pixel-branded smartphones and a smart home speaker that competes with Amazon's Echo. Google's Q3 net revenue — despite higher traffic acquisition costs (TAC) costs of $4.18 billion — was $18.27 billion, topping views.Alphabet shares nearly hit a record high Friday morning, but closed the day fractionally higher and the week fractionally lower, but still in buy range.Tesla Motors earned 71 cents a share excluding items, soundly beating the consensus estimate of a 54-cent loss. Revenue climbed 45% to $2.3 billion, up 45% and topping estimates of $1.977 billion. Elon Musk had pushed Tesla to boost deliveries and turn a profit in Q3, but some analysts are skeptical that the effort is sustainable. Tesla maintained its guidance of 50,000 vehicle deliveries for the second half of 2016, with a Q4 plan of just over 25,000.Tesla and SolarCity (SCTY) late Friday were expected to unveil an integrated product offering of solar panels, battery storage and charger. Tesla is in the process of buying SolarCity. Elon Musk is the top shareholder in both companies, as well as SpaceX.Tesla found resistance at the 50-day line and reversed, ending the week down 12 cents at 199.97. SolarCity climbed 2.7%.Gigamon (GIMO) reported third quarter profit and revenue that blew past estimates and raised current quarter guidance. Santa Clara, Calif.-based Gigamon said Q3 EPS minus items rose 64% to 36 cents, while revenue jumped 47% to $83.5 million. Analysts had projected 31 cents and $79.6 million. In the current quarter, Gigamon forecast EPS of 37 cents and revenue of $92 million at its midpoint of guidance vs. consensus estimates of 33 cent profit and 29% revenue growth to $86 million. Analysts say AT&T (T) may be a new customer, joining T-Mobile US (TMUS).Gigamon shot up 16.1% Friday, hitting a record high intraday. Shares had fallen 5.2% Thursday to below its 50-day line.Lumentum (LITE) said Q1 EPS rose 69% to 44 cents and revenue climbed 19% to $252.3 million, topping expectations but current quarter revenue guidance was light amid a telecom component shortage from an unnamed supplier. EPS guidance of 51 cents at the midpoint was above consensus estimates of 49 cents. Lumentum fell 3.7% after its late Thursday report, but that followed a 4.3% fall Thursday as Acacia Communications (ACIA) crashed 16% that day and for the week. Chinese telecom gear giant ZTE, a key Acacia customer, reported weak revenue.Qualcomm announced a deal to buy NXP Semiconductors for $39 billion, creating the No. 2 chipmaker by revenue after Intel (INTC). Including debt, the deal is worth $47 billion. Mobile-communications chipmaker Qualcomm said the acquisition will expand its footprint into key growth markets, including automotive, Internet of Things, security and networking. The Qualcomm-NXP transaction marks the biggest semiconductor deal ever, surpassing Avago Technologies' $37 billion purchase of Broadcom (AVGO).New Oriental Education and Technology (EDU) met fiscal Q1 EPS views with a 15% gain to 90 cents. Revenue climbed 16.5%, above analysts' expectations, as enrollment boomed. The IBD 50 stock sees Q2 revenue above analyst guidance. Fellow Chinese for-profit school stock TAL Education (XRS) Q2 results topped estimates as total student enrollment jumped 77%. It guided Q3 revenue above Wall Street views. New Oriental stock rose more than 10% for the week, blasting out of a base to a new high. TAL Education climbed 12%, also to a high.RELATED:New Oriental Education Breaks Out On Strong Revenue, GuidanceTAL Education Stock Enters Profit-Taking Sell Territory After Q2 BeatChipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) earned 27 cents a share, down 94%, while revenue fell nearly 15% to $1.04 billion, both worse than expected. Same-store sales tumbled 21.9% as fast-casual burrito chain still struggles to recover from late 2015 food-borne illness outbreaks. Shares fell 9% Wednesday, hitting a 3-year low. Panera Bread (PNRA) beat views, sending the stock higher intraday Wednesday, but reversed lower, falling to an eight-month low on Thursday. Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) met EPS views and missed on sales, but shares rose 6% Thursday from recent lows.Food delivery services provider GrubHub (GRUB) reported that EPS rose 73% and revenue 44%, both topping. But Grubhub's active diners rose by 19%, missing estimates slightly. Shares, which had been near an 18-month high, fell nearly 13% on Wednesday, tumbling below its 50-day line.Biogen (BIIB) posted $2.96 billion in sales and $5.19 EPS ex items, topping views and prodding shares up nearly 4%. Thursday, Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) rose 5%, Celgene (CELG) 7% and Alexion (ALXN) 9% after beating on earnings. Amgen (AMGN) late Thursday beat, but shares tumbled nearly 10% Friday amid concerns about key drug Enbrel going forward. Also Friday, Novo Nordisk (NVO) dived 13% and Sanofi (SNY) rose 4.3%, as the European drugmakers had different views on the outlook for insulin treatments.Meanwhile, drug distributor McKesson (MCK) crashed 22.7% Friday after a big miss, blaming rival AmerisourceBergen (ABC) for heavy competition and further pressure from political attention on drug prices. AmerisourceBergen fell 13% and Cardinal Health (CAH) nearly 10%, with both reporting earnings next week.RELATED:Bristol-Myers, Celgene Stocks Rocket After Sweeping Q3 ExpectationsBiogen Q3 Tops; Alzheimer's Data Vs. Eli Lilly PositiveAlexion Crushes Q3 Expectations; Stock Bounds On Drug Trial PlansAbiomed (ABMD) fell short on earnings, sending shares tumbling 7% on Thursday. Edwards Lifesciences (EW) revenue came in light at $739.4 million, with sales guidance also light, sending shares plunging 17%. Boston Scientific (BSX) stock fell modestly after EPS met and sales topped. Stryker (SYK) narrowly topped EPS and sales views late Thursday, sending shares up 4.1% Friday.Third-quarter GDP growth topped forecasts withe fastest growth in two years. But consumer spending growth slowed significantly, while business investment remained weak. Real final sales, which exclude inventory gains and next exports, slowed to 1.4% from 2.4%. Separately, durable goods orders edged lower, with core capital goods demand falling the most since February.Boeing (BA) said there's a "realistic possibility" it will launch a new midsize plane and a longer version of its 737 Max, as it seeks to counter gains from Airbus (EADSY). Boeing's Q3 results topped analyst views. Revenue from its commercial airplanes division fell 4% and defense revenue fell 10%.Boeing shares rose 5.4% to 143.01 for the week, breaking out of a base to a 2016 high.RELATED: Boeing: 'Realistic Possibility' Of Midsize Jet, Stretch 737; Stock In Buy ZoneLockheed Martin (LMT) topped Q3 views and the defense giant raised its full-year outlook, while the next two production batches of the F-35 could be split into separate contracts. Northrop Grumman (NOC) raised its full-year guidance after reporting Q3 results above analyst views, sending the stock into buy territory. Raytheon's Q3 EPS topped estimates but revenue was light and the Patriot missile system maker's improved guidance still fell short of Wall Street views.RELATED: Lockheed Soars On Outlook, Payout; Next F-35 Contract Seen SplitNorthrop Stock Enters Buy Range On Strong Outlook, Q3 BeatBombs Lift Raytheon's Q3 But Outlook Is A Dud; Stock DivesExxon Mobil (XOM) topped Q3 EPS estimates but revenue fell well short. Capital spending fell 45% and oil production dipped 5.1%. Chevron (CVX) crushed EPS views while revenue missed slightly. Downstream profits were down at both oil majors as refining margins weakened. ConocoPhillips' (COP) Q3 loss wasn't as bad as expected and the company raised its full-year production outlook, while lowering its capital spending guidance.General Electric (GE) is in talks with oil services firm Baker Hughes (BHI) about partnerships, but not an "outright purchase." Baker Hughes broke out into a buy zone on Tuesday after reporting better-than-expected earnings. It added 8.4% Friday.Industrial giants United Technologies (UTX), Caterpillar (CAT) and 3M (MMM) all issued weak financial forecasts, with global economic uncertainty hurting the sector broadly. General Electric (GE) and several other notable industrial firms already had cut guidance. General Motors (GM), meanwhile, warned about the impact of Brexit and a "plateaued" U.S. auto market despite strong full-year EPS guidance overall.The athletic apparel maker's earnings rose 23% and sales 22%, both topping views. But gross margins dipped amid "negative impacts from the timing of liquidation, increased promotions, and foreign exchange rates." Under Armour (UA) sees Q4 revenue growth of 20% below consensus for 22.2%. Under Armour vowed to invest "aggressively." Shares fell more than 18% for the wee, hitting a 2-year low.RELATED:Under Armour Dives On Growth Targets; Execs Vow To Invest 'Aggressively'

Stock ETFs posted broad losses Thursday as investors digested a slew of corporate earnings, a major semiconductor deal and a bounce in oil prices. Bond ETFs were bruised across the board.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) gave back early gains to dip 0.2% on the stock market today.This exchange traded fund serves as a proxy for the broad U.S. market and sits 2% below the late August high of 219.60.Shares in Qualcomm (QCOM), one of its 505 stock holdings, jumped following news that the semiconductor firm will buy leading automotive chipmaker NXP Semiconductor (NXPI) for $38 billion.Health care and financials were the only two sectors to post a gain in the S&P 500. Real estate fared worst, down 2.3%.First Trust Dow Jones Internet (FDN) closed 0.9% lower and could be poised for more losses tomorrow.Its No. 1 holding Amazon (AMZN) tumbled as much as 7% in after-hours trade after posting a smaller-than-expected growth in profits.Another top-five holding, Alphabet (GOOGL), beat estimates and rose after the closing bell.LinkedIn (LNKD) was virtually unchanged after hours following its report.Shares in Twitter (TWTR), a smaller stock holding in the internet ETF, ended lower despite beating views on the top and bottom lines. The microblog service announced it would lay off 9% of its workers.FDN has underperformed several technology exchange traded funds year to date, but is ahead of the S&P 500 with a 10.1% gain through Oct. 26.Its sits 1% below the all-time high of 83.10, set Monday.IBD'S TAKE: Qualcomm and NXP are members of IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group, which currently ranks No. 7 out of 197 groups. But neither are in the top five companies in the group. To see which stocks are leading the group, visit the IBD Stock Checkup.West Texas Intermediate (WTI) settled up at $49.72 a barrel on brighter hopes for a deal to curb crude oil output among OPEC and non-OPEC nations.United States Oil (USO), a commodity ETF investing in near-month WTI futures, bounced 1.1% higher — its first gain so far this week.Bond ETFs finished lower as the 10-year Treasury yield hits its highest level since June 2, at 1.834%. Bond yields move inversely to their price.Here's how major exchange traded funds across major asset classes performed today, with IBD Relative Strength Ratings.The RS Rating is a measure of a stock's price performance over the last 12 months, compared with all stocks and ETFs, on a scale of 1 to a best-possible 99.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), -0.3%, RS 53PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), -0.5%, RS 69SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), -0.1%, RS 53IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), -0.8%, RS 58IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), -1.1%, RS 61IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), -0.1%, RS 40Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), -0.8%, RS 73SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), +0.2%, RS 49United States Oil (USO), +1.1%, RS 58IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), -0.3%, RS 40PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), +0.2%, RS 49IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), +1.8%, RS 2

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Wednesday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day. Tesla Motors' (TSLA) quarterly results should go back to black, Boeing (BA) is near buying territory ahead of its report, while GrubHub (GRUB) is extended above an entry point. Biogen (BIIB) and NXP Semiconductor (NXPI) are also due to report. Tesla…

Mobile chipmaker Qualcomm (QCOM) is near a deal to acquire Dutch chipmaker NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), Bloomberg reported Thursday afternoon.NXP stock shot up as much as 2.7% on the stock market today on the initial report but ended the day up 1%, at 103.49. Qualcomm stock rose 1.1% Thursday, to 67.54.NXP stock has soared over 25% since news reports first broke last week about a possible marriage between the semiconductor firms. Qualcomm is up 6% in the same period.Qualcomm is the only company in talks to buy NXP and is just haggling over price, Bloomberg said. San Diego-based Qualcomm is targeting a price near 110 a share, or roughly $35 billion, while Netherlands-based NXP is looking for about 120, roughly $41 billion, the news service said. Qualcomm also is angling for a deal structure of 75% cash and 25% stock, while NXP wants all cash, sources told Bloomberg.The deal would create the second-largest chip company by revenue, after Intel (INTC).IBD'S TAKE: Big mergers come with big risks, and many never pan out. An example of a huge deal that so far is working out is Broadcom's $37 billion acquisition of Avago Technologies, completed Feb. 1. Broadcom currently ranks No. 26 on the IBD 50 list of top-performing public companies. What's more, Broadcom is among IBD's Sector Leaders.An acquisition of NXP would help Qualcomm diversify beyond mobile-phone chips. The deal would give Qualcomm exposure to the automotive, industrial and Internet of Things markets.Purchasing NXP would allow Qualcomm to become an end-to-end chip supplier to the automotive market.RELATED:Qualcomm Gets More Upbeat Reviews On NXP Semi Merger RumorAnalysts Bullish On Possible Qualcomm-NXP Merger

U.S. stock indexes slipped near midday Thursday in surprisingly strong volume on the eve of a GDP report.The Nasdaq clipped off 0.2%, the S&P 500 was essentially flat and the blue chip Dow Jones industrial average added 0.2%. Volume in the stock market today on both exchanges was tracking higher than Wednesday's levels.Market risk remains elevated, with six distribution days on the Nasdaq and S&P 500. Signs of institutional selling like this make it a tough environment for stocks to make meaningful headway.IBD'S TAKE: An investor shouldn't trash other investment strategies. Still, it's best to be aware of  the arguments surrounding market timing and buy and hold.The first take on Q3 GDP will be released Friday morning before the open. The Street expects 2.5% growth, which would be the best in the past five quarters. The range of estimates spans 2.2% to 3.1%.While the indexes weren't doing much Thursday, a few stocks outperformed.Big cap biotech Celgene (CELG) gapped up 6% in volume more than 450% above average. The company topped the Street's estimate on Q3 earnings by nearly 7%. Revenue came in more than 4% above expectations. The maker of therapies for cancer and inflammatory diseases also raised guidance.Celgene's chart has work to do. The stock is about 19% off its 52-week high. The stock's most recent breakout came in July when Celgene cleared a base within a larger consolidation. However, the double-bottom pattern with a 108.60 entry lacked a prior uptrend of 30%, and the breakout failed.Qualcomm (QCOM) gapped up 3% on news that the mega-cap company would acquire NXP Semiconductors (NXPI). Because of regulatory reviews, the deal isn't expected to close until late 2017. NXP rose 1%. Thursday's news had been rumored since late September and both stocks made big moves Sept. 29.Pipeline play Antero Midstream Partners (AM) gapped up 5%, hitting a 52-week high. The stock is somewhat thinly traded, but has delivered triple-digit earnings gains in three of the past four quarters. Antero reported quarterly results Wednesday, beating the Street's estimates on the top and bottom line.In economic news, first-time jobless claims were a bit more than expected. Durable goods orders for September missed the consensus target, but the prior reading was revised upward. Pending home sales in September topped the Street's estimate.

It was anything but a dull week on the stock market. On the IBD 50 list, three stocks scored breakouts. At least five broke down and flashed sell signals. But the group's overall status remained solid, with about 20% of the IBD 50 at or near new highs and another 20% still in valid bases. That means there is good…

Stocks opened modestly higher Thursday as earnings reports continued to roll out before the opening bell.The Dow industrials and S&P 500 gained 0.2% and the Nasdaq traded up 0.3%.Big-name earnings news powered early action on the stock market today, with the likes of Ford (F), ConocoPhillips (COP), Western Digital (WDC) and Tesla Motors (TSLA) in play.NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) climbed less than 2% as Qualcomm (QCOM) jumped 4%. Qualcomm agreed to buy the Netherlands-based chip maker for $39 billion. NXP, a leading chip supplier to automotive markets, sets up Qualcomm -- primarily a cell-phone chipmaker -- to pursue autonomous driving applications.  Qualcomm is rebounding from its third test of support at the 10-week line since a breakout in July.Tesla Motors upshifted 4% on a big third-quarter earnings beat reported after Wednesday's close. Revenue met expectations and the company topped its delivery targets. Tesla shares have been locked in a weakening consolidation since April.F5 Networks (FFIV) leapt 9% at the open. The network optimization specialist's fiscal fourth-quarter revenue and earnings both topped expectations. Shares broke out past the 126.07 buy point in a two-month double-bottom base.IBD 50 stock Planet Fitness (PLNT) crunched a 3% advance at the open. The gym chain's third quarter sales and earnings easily topped views, and lifted full-year revenue guidance to above consensus estimates.  Shares ended Wednesday up 5% so far for the week, in a bid to retake support at their 10-week moving average.Ford opened 1% lower. The automaker's third-quarter earnings slipped less, revenue fell slightly more than expected by analysts. Ford shares have been in a gradual downtrend since July 2014.ConocoPhillips swung up more than 2% after reporting better-than-forecast third-quarter results. The company raised its production outlook and cut capital spending targets.Western Digital scaled up 5% following a healthy fiscal first-quarter beat reported late Wednesday.Colgate Palmolive (CL) rose 0.5% after missing analysts revenue targets.First time jobless claims continued to tick lower, according to the Labor Department, dipping to 258,000 in the week ended Oct. 22. That was down from the prior week's upwardly revised 261,000 claims, but above consensus projections for a fall to 255,000 claims. The four-week moving average edged up to 253,000, a second straight increase.Orders for durable goods eased 0.1% in September, the Commerce Department said. That reversed August's orders, which the department revised upward to a 0.3% increase. Minus transportation, orders rose 0.2%, topping an upwardly revised 0.1% increase in August, as well as views for another 0.1% increase.September pending home sales numbers from the National Association of Realtors roll out at 10 a.m.Narrow losses were the order of business across Asia's markets on Thursday. Afternoon trade in Europe turned mixed, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.3% and Freankfurt's DAX up 0.3%.  Oil futures traded modestly higher, but West Texas Intermediate still lagged below $50 a barrel. Gold climbed a fraction, to $1,270 an ounce. The dollar rose vs. the yen, but slipped vs. the euro. The 10-year yield jumped 4 basis points to 1.83% as bonds eased.A crowded docket of companies, including Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet (GOOGL), Amgen (AMGN) and many others, will be out with earnings after the close.RELATED:Tesla Q3 Earnings Go Full Throttle, Topping EstimatesConoco Raises 2016 Production Outlook, Lowers Spending GuidanceWill Cash-Rich Google Announce New Stock Buyback With Earnings?

Scanning IBD DataTables for income ideas was a lot easier earlier this year.Even the IBD 50, the premier list of strength in the stock market, was littered with stocks sporting healthy dividends, especially from the utilities and real estate investment trusts (REITs).Contrast that to today, when a screen of utilities leaders only yielded a couple names as of Wednesday's close, both of them breaking support levels. A screen of REIT leaders offers a dozen names but only one is above its 50-day moving average and none has a Relative Price Strength Rating above 80.The Dividend Leaders screen, however, does have a few ideas of interest. Particularly, noteworthy are a couple chip stocks, Qualcomm (QCOM) and Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM).Qualcomm is still a dominant force in the mobile-phone market with its chip designs in mobile products of Apple (AAPL), Samsung, and now Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google Pixel. While, no one is expecting Qualcomm to "party like its 1999" when it ran up over 2,000%, it still offers an attractive dividend with the potential for capital appreciation.Granted, Qualcomm doesn't have the triple-digit earnings growth it had in its youth. In fact, prior to its 17% growth for its fiscal Q3 in 2016, the company saw four consecutive quarters of profit declines. Qualcomm is scheduled to report its fourth quarter, ended in September, on Nov. 2 after the close.March 2016 saw a completion of a one-year commitment to repurchase $10 billion in stock and the quarterly dividend was raised to 53 cents earlier this year. That was the 15th dividend increase since 2003, putting the annualized yield at 3.2%.The most recent news on Qualcomm is the rumors of a potential acquisition of NXP Semiconductors (NXPI). NXP makes high-performance mixed signal processors for communications, security, automotive and industrial applications. An acquisition of NXP offers more diversity for Qualcomm beyond the heavy reliance on mobile. Particularly interesting is the exposure to the auto-related chips, a fast-growing field.Meanwhile, Maxim is noteworthy for the current base its carving out. The stock is working on a base-on-base structure with its current flat base showing support right on top of the cup with handle formed earlier. The stock is currently trying to get back above its 50-day moving average, closing right at the line on Thursday.Maxim is a chipmaker specializing in integrated circuits for autos, cloud data centers, industrial and mobile applications. It has an annualized dividend yield of 3.3%. The company is reporting Q1 fiscal 2017 earnings on Oct. 20.Earlier this year, Maxim was also in the takeover buzz as a possible acquisition by Texas Instruments (TXN).The chart might seem like a real bore since there have actually been multiple bases formed at this point that haven't seemed able to launch. However, that action is not without precedent.Before Qualcomm's huge run in 1999, it also had multiple bases that didn't go anywhere, until it formed a near-perfect cup with handle that launched the stock for good. Of course, that was a different time with not only Qualcomm's earnings growth acting as a catalyst but also a strong market providing a powerful tailwind.RELATED:NXP Hires Advisor To Field Offers As Qualcomm CirclesQualcomm Gets More Upbeat Reviews on NXP Semi Merger RumorWhere Are Chipmakers In The Cycle

Samsung's decision to cancel production and sales of its problem-plagued Galaxy Note 7 smartphone is likely to have a "modest negative impact" on several mobile-chip suppliers, Pacific Crest Research said Tuesday.Semiconductor manufacturers with the most exposure to Samsung business include Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM), Synaptics (SYNA), Qualcomm (QCOM) and Qorvo (QRVO).Maxim has the highest exposure to Samsung, with the South Korean tech giant accounting for 4.2% of Maxim's revenue, Pacific Crest said in a research report. Synaptics is second with 2.9% of revenue from Samsung, followed by Qualcomm (2.7%) and Qorvo (2.3%), the investment bank said.IBD'S TAKE: The semiconductor industry has been the source of some top-performing stocks lately. Eight chip-sector stocks are now on the IBD 50 list of top-performing companies.Conversely, Samsung's Galaxy Note 7 black-eye could drive more business to Apple's (AAPL) iPhone family, Pacific Crest said.Canaccord Genuity analyst Michael Walkley said the Galaxy Note 7 recall will have a "slight impact to near-term estimates" for Qualcomm.Qualcomm stock, which touched a four-month high above 70 on Sept. 30, slipped 3 cents in the stock market today to close at 66.06. Synaptics stock rose a fraction Wednesday, while Maxim and Qorvo each fell a fraction.In his research report on Qualcomm, Walkley said, "We are slightly lowering our MSM (mobile station modem) shipment estimates for the December and March quarters following the Samsung Galaxy Note 7 discontinuation of production, as Qualcomm supplies the higher ASP (average selling price) Snapdragon 820 (processor) for this smartphone."Walkley reiterated his buy rating on Qualcomm stock and raised his price target to 75 from 70. He is bullish on Qualcomm's opportunities with Chinese handset makers, such as Vivo and Oppo. Walkley also is positive on Qualcomm's rumored interest in acquiring of NXP Semiconductors (NXPI).RELATED:Qualcomm Close To Giving Final Rose To NXP SemiconductorsApple Stock Rises On Price-Target Hike, Improved Sentiment

Major stock ETFs closed higher for the week, with investors cheering two key tech earnings and news of a semiconductor deal Friday.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) posted a 0.4% weekly gain, led higher by the materials sector while utilities trailed. This exchange traded fund serves as a proxy for the broad U.S. market and sits 2% below its August high of 219.60.Shares of two out of roughly 500 holdings struck record highs on the stock market today.Microsoft (MSFT) jumped 4.3%, climbing as high as 60.45 after the company reported solid results from its cloud unit as it pivots away from a hardware-focused business model.PayPal (PYPL) gapped up 10.0%, rising as much as 44.24 after reporting it grew active customer accounts and revenue.Among other holdings, chipmaker Qualcomm (QCOM) rose 0.9% amid news that the company is nearing a deal for NXP Semiconductors (NXPI).IBD'S TAKE: Microsoft stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 65, meaning it has outperformed 65% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For a list of better-performing stocks, check out the IBD 50.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) advanced 1.2% on the week after three weeks of losses amid a rising dollar and rate-hike fears. The commodity ETF tracks the spot price of gold.Gold's gains propelled silver and gold mining stocks to some of the best weekly gains across the nonleveraged ETF landscape.VanEck Vectors Gold Miners (GDX) gained 7.1% on the week to retake the 40-week moving average. A smaller peer vaulted 11% in the same period."If you are looking for places to add a little capital that can protect you from the election-inspired uncertainties in the market, gold deserves strong consideration," Doug Fabian, president of Fabian Wealth Strategies, wrote in his Oct. 21 Weekly ETF Report.Here's how major exchange traded funds across major asset classes performed today, with IBD Relative Strength Ratings.The RS Rating is a measure of a stock's price performance over the last 12 months, compared with all stocks and ETFs, on a scale of 1 to a best-possible 99.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), 0%, RS 53PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), +0.4%, RS 65SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), -0.2%, RS 48IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), 0%, RS 60IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), 0%, RS 65IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), -0.2%, RS 44Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), 0%, RS 72SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), +0.1%, RS 48United States Oil (USO), +0.4%, RS 63IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), +0.1%, RS 40PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), +0.4%, RS 40IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), -2.2%, RS 1

Here's your weekly Investing Action Plan: what you need to know as an investor for the coming week. Tech darlings Apple (AAPL), Tesla Motors (TSLA), Amazon (AMZN) and Alphabet (GOOGL) will report earnings as well as aerospace and defense leaders Boeing (BA) and Lockheed Martin (LMT). Industrial giants, big biotechs and medical device makers will weigh in too, as will oil…

With chipmakers the No. 2 sector in IBD's tables, three semiconductor ETFs have earned spots in the ETF Leaders screen.All three ETFs are tracing similar chart patterns: After strong gains from July breakouts, they are pausing at the 50-day moving average. A rise from the line would provide ETF traders with a chance to buy shares. While tactically there's a buy opportunity, keep in mind that these ETFs have already made a big jump -- up 18% to 28% this year. Thus, investors have a difficult decision on whether to use one of these ETFs to gain exposure to the hot sector.VanEck Vector Semiconductor (SMH) and iShares PHLX Semiconductor (SOXX) bulk up on the industry titans. Qualcomm (QCOM), Intel (INTC), Broadcom (AVGO), Texas Instruments (TXN) and Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) are among the largest holdings of both funds.Those stocks have made moderate to solid gains this year, and are no doubt largely responsible for the ETFs' advance. But Nvidia (NVDA), another top holding of the funds, has had a superlative 2016, more than doubling since a breakout in mid-March. Best known for graphics chips, Nvidia is now a big player is the technology to design self-driving cars.The iShares Semiconductor ETF mimics the Philadelphia semiconductor index, or SOX as it's best known. It has 30 companies, which include the industry heavyweights.SPDR S&P Semiconductor (XSD) ETF has a markedly different composition than the other two. That may explain why the ETF has lagged the other two. It's up 18% year to date (through Thursday's close), while VanEck Semiconductors has climbed nearly 28% and iShares Semiconductors 23%.The major components of SPDR S&P Semiconductor aren't all big-capitalization stocks, but also include small-caps and midcaps such as Synaptics (SYNA) (market cap of $2.4 billion), Cirrus Logic (CRUS) ($3.4 billion) and solar-power module maker First Solar (FSLR) ($4.3 billion).SPDR S&P Semiconductor tracks an index of chip companies selected mainly for their revenue but also earnings, market capitalization and "market perception," as the prospectus says.IBD's chip sector is up about 17% this year, thanks in part to higher-than-expected demand for the new Apple iPhone 7, increasing use of electronics in the home (the Internet of Things) and chips in cars. Even with the flop of the Samsung Note 7, the chip sector has been one of 2016's winners. Broadcom and Qualcomm are suppliers to iPhone and Samsung smartphones.The information technology sector continues to lead with the most positive earnings guidance. For Q3, that includes eight of 15 S&P 500 companies in semiconductor and chip equipment, according to a Sept. 28 report by FactSet.The IBD ETF Leaders index shows the performance of a model portfolio of exchange traded funds that are leading the overall market. A computer algorithm selects the ETFs based on relative strength and other objective performance ratings, with periodic adjustments for market trends and conditions. The universe from which the ETFs are selected includes the funds listed below.          RELATED:KLA-Tencor, AMD, Maxim Integrated Earnings Top Views; Chip Stocks DivergeIntel Beats Q3 Targets, But Q4 Sales Forecast Lags
