Avago Technologies (AVGO) stock steamrolled the IBD Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group in 2015, rocketing 45% since January on its chipmaking link to the golden smartphone goose. But other Apple (AAPL) suppliers weren't as lucky.Qualcomm (QCOM) and Qorvo (QRVO) stocks have plunged 32% and 22%, respectively, since January. Both trail their IBD performance groups in spades and face ongoing Asian headwinds that include a challenge from China's Tsinghua Unigroup to unseat Qualcomm from its No. 3 chip slot.Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSM), too, underperformed its IBD Electronics-Semiconductor Manufacturing industry group, by rising 2% in 2015 vs. the group's collective 3% rise.And every supplier, according to analysts, will likely feel hunger pangs as Apple appears likely to cut its orders in the typically tough March quarter while facing an iPhone sales drought.Intraday on the stock market today, nearly every Apple chip supplier dipped and Cirrus Logic (CRUS) stock led the way as shares fell about 3% ahead of the new year. Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) stock followed and was down 1.5% midday Thursday.Broadcom (BRCM) and Taiwan Semiconductor stocks, alone, managed to stay in the green and were up fractionally in midday trading.Avago's Blowout 2015Without a doubt, Avago had a blowout 2015 and consistently topped quarterly Wall Street views. The chipmaker ended its fiscal year 2015 (in November) with $8.98 earnings per share ex items on $6.9 billion in sales, up 83% and 60% vs. 2014.In December, eight analysts rated Avago stock a buy.But the company's growth is slowing. During the first half of 2015, Avago posted triple-digit earnings and sales growth. In Q3 and Q4, those numbers braked to double-digit growth. Now the consensus of 26 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters largely expects single-digit growth in 2016.The $37 billion plan to acquire Broadcom could buoy those figures. Avago announced its plan to acquire Apple rival Broadcom in May, shortly after it promised to buy data connector Emulex for $606 million in February. The deal is expected to close in Q1.Avago's Broadcom deal was one of more than $100 billion in chip sector deals in 2015. Analysts say semiconductor M&A activity will continue in 2016 as, such is Avago's plight, growth slows, competition mounts and the economy lags.Qualcomm Snagged In ChinaChinese licensing negotiations pummeled Qualcomm in 2015 and led to an internal review spurred by activist investor JANA Partners that would have seen the chipmaker split.But Qualcomm recently decided against jettisoning its licensing business. CEO Steve Mollenkopf told investors earlier this month, "The strategic benefits of our model are not replicable through alternative structures."That model has caused particular ire in China. Qualcomm settled an anti-monopoly suit with China's National Development and Reform Commission in February but has since struggled to collect royalties from Chinese smartphone makers."We believe in connection with the negotiations, (some licensees) have stopped reporting certain of their sales and royalties or did not report their sales and royalties in a manner that allows us to record revenue," Qualcomm President Derek Aberle told investors in November.Authorities in Taiwan have since launched an antitrust investigation into Qualcomm's licensing business, following in the footsteps of similar probes in China and South Korea. The European Commission also recently alleged that Qualcomm paid a major customer to use its chips exclusively and engaged in "predatory pricing" to force competitors out of the market.For its fiscal Q4, Qualcomm reported an 18% dip in sales to $5.5 billion and 91 cents EPS minus items, down 28% vs. the year-earlier quarter. Both measures, however, beat the consensus model.Qualcomm ended fiscal 2015 with $25.3 billion in sales and $4.66 EPS minus items, down 5% and 12%, respectively, vs. fiscal 2014. The consensus of 36 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters currently sees Qualcomm's fiscal 2016 sales and EPS ex items dropping 8% and 11%, respectively.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

The stock market today leaned toward another positive send-off, mustering almost as much momentum as in Tuesday's premarket session. Dow Jones, Nasdaq 100 and S&P 500 futures all steered 1% higher and had improved over the prior hour.European markets traded firmly higher, with London's FTSE 100, Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC-40 in Paris all up more than 1% at midday. China's markets ended sharply mixed, with the Shanghai Composite suffering a 2.4% loss. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 spiked 2.9%,A mild day for economic news includes the Atlanta Federal Reserve's Business Inflation Expectations index, out at 10 a.m. ET. Weekly crude oil inventories data at 10:30 from the Energy Information Administration. The Federal Reserve's January Beige Book report is due out at 2 p.m.Oil traded up more than 2%, to just above $31 a barrel.Stocks moving on upgrades included Microsoft (MSFT) and Qualcomm (QCOM), up more than 1% each, and Pulte (PHM), with a 2% gain.Life insurer MetLife (MET) powered up 6% in early action. The New York-based firm jumped in after-hours trade Tuesday following the company's announcement that it planned to spin off its retail insurance business, totaling about $240 billion in assets and about 20% of the overall company's operating earnings.The timing of the spin-off will depend on a Securities and Exchange Commission review, the company said. MetLife shares have been in a deepening consolidation since July.Israel-based security software developer CyberArk Software (CYBR) flashed 11% higher after news reports said Check Point Software (CHKP), also an Israeli company, was considering a buyout bid. Details were scant and the companies declined to comment, according to Reuters. CyberArk has been struggling in a worsening correction since June.Among leaders, Avago Technologies (AVGO) traded down more than 3% in premarket action. The stock recovered losses Tuesday to end with 1% gain and back above its 200-day moving average, despite analysts continuing to backtrack on initial forecasts for 2016 shipments of Apple's (AAPL) iPhones. Avago supplies components used in the devices.On Wednesday, Qualcomm and TDK announced a joint venture for RF front-end modules for mobile devices, sending shares of Apple suppliers lower.Avago is fighting to hold support at its 200-day line, deep below a 149.82 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Just as the stock market goes through a correction, earnings for the tech companies in the S&P 500 are expected to record their first year-over-year decline in the past 10 quarters.A slowing China, weak global economy, strong dollar, poor PC sales and the shift to cloud computing continue to weigh on the tech sector, and the top tech companies' Q4 EPS are seen falling for the first time since Q2 2013."Tech remains stuck in a low-growth environment, and the interaction of rising interest rates, a strong dollar, weak oil and commodities are increasing risk," said Bill Whyman, head of technology strategy research at Evercore ISI.Tech spending growth generally is slow, says Whyman, but he adds that underneath the surface, there is an aggressive shift in spending that favors companies connected to cloud computing, including providers of software-as-a-service (SaaS) platforms and young, disruptive Internet companies.Apple, Facebook, Amazon Earnings On TapThus far, 13 of the 68 tech companies in the S&P 500 have reported earnings, including Intel (INTC) and IBM (IBM), which both provided tepid guidance that sent their shares falling.The tech earnings season gets into full swing starting Tuesday, with the biggest company of them all — Apple (AAPL) — set to report that day after the market close amid fast falling expectations for sales of its top product, the iPhone. On Wednesday comes Facebook (FB) and Qualcomm (QCOM), both after the close. On Thursday it's Amazon (AMZN) and Microsoft (MSFT), also after the close. Google-owner Alphabet (GOOGL) reports on Monday, Feb. 1, after the close.The consensus estimate for the 68 tech companies in the S&P 500 is for earnings per share minus items to fall 3.4% from the year-earlier quarter, the fourth quarter in a row of deceleration. Subtracting Apple, which has the largest impact of any company in S&P 500, tech earnings would fall 6.7%, according to estimates collected by Thomson Reuters.For the S&P 500 as a whole, analysts call for EPS ex items, such as stock options and one-time expenses, to fall 4.5%. That drop is largely due to the ailing energy sector, which is expected to see its EPS tumble 73%. Excluding the energy sector, EPS is expected to rise 1.6% overall.Tech companies have long been the innovation trendsetters, turning in strong earnings that usually put the industry at or near the top of the best-performing groups in the S&P 500. Not now. In terms of earnings performance, tech is in the middle of the pack among the 10 industry groups in the S&P 500."The tech sector is now more of a mirror of the S&P index as whole," said Gregory Harrison, earnings analyst at Thomson Reuters.The tech industry has been stuck in slow-growth mode at the same time it's going through a once-in-a-decade secular shift — the move to cloud computing — which has shattered old ways of using technology, says Evercore ISI's Whyman. Rather than buy large computer servers and storage systems for business operations, companies and other enterprises are lowering costs by turning to Internet-based cloud computing services provided by companies such as Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet.Cloud Computing Drives TechnologyCloud computing is the dominant force in technology and will continue to accelerate, says Whyman. Among other things, cloud computing has spurred the emergence of SaaS, provided on demand as needed. SaaS leaders include Salesforce.com (CRM).Moreover, many providers of cloud services are buying lower-cost hardware from Taiwan and mainland China, opting for stripped-down hardware of their own design instead of brand-name products. That is rattling some of the largest information technology companies, such as IBM, Cisco Systems (CSCO), Oracle (ORCL) and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE), all of which are undergoing major transitions.This disruption is happening amid slower sales of PCs and now-slowing growth for smartphones and tablets.Global PC shipments fell 8.3% in the fourth quarter vs. Q4 2014, to just under 76 million units, according to preliminary results by market tracker Gartner. It was the fifth consecutive quarter of year-over-year shipment declines. For the year, PC shipments fell 8% to 288.7 million units. Gartner expects PC shipments to fall this year as well, but only by 1%, and it anticipates a soft recovery later in 2016.Global semiconductor sales fell 2% in 2015 to $334 billion, Gartner says, attributed not just to PCs, but also in part to weakened demand for electronic equipment amid the cloud shift and the continuing impact of the strong dollar.Strong Dollar Hurts Tech ResultsThe strong dollar, which makes U.S. exports more expensive, is more difficult for tech companies than other sectors."A big variable remains the U.S. dollar, as it has a huge impact on tech," said Whyman. "Tech derives more revenue from outside the U.S. than any other S&P sector."Apple, despite the popularity of its products and huge size, is not immune to the fallout. When Apple reports earnings on Tuesday, its performance in China will be closely watched. China accounted for an estimated 25% of all iPhone sales in 2015. Slower economic growth in China and slower sales of smartphones globally are expected to pressure its earnings growth. The consensus on Apple is EPS growth of 6% year over year, which would be its slowest growth in eight quarters.As always, analysts will focus on corporate guidance, and the outlook might be especially important in this earnings cycle amid a rough start to 2016 for global stock markets."The range of uncertainty is widening, so there is a greater interest in clues as to what 2016 might hold," Whyman said.Among the 12 subsectors in the S&P 500 tech group, application software leads with an expected average EPS increase of 44%. The group includes Adobe Systems (ADBE) and Salesforce.com.The Internet software and services group is expected to have the second-best performance among the tech subsectors. This includes Facebook and Alphabet, which continue to ride the rising tide of mobile and online ad growth. Facebook is expected to show EPS growth of 26%, while Alphabet is expected to post growth of 18%.Friday, some of the biggest tech companies reporting earnings in the coming week rose ahead of the major stock market indexes.Apple stock lifted 5.3% to 101.42, Facebook gained 4% to 97.94, Amazon rose 3.7% to 596.38 and Microsoft logged a 3.6% boost to 52.29.

Popular video games "Star Wars Battlefront" and the latest installment of "Call of Duty" buoyed gaming chipmakers Nvidia (NVDA) and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) in 2015, an MKM analyst wrote Wednesday, as he suggested Nvidia could leapfrog its main game rival in 2016.But that will require Nvidia to slash its GPU (graphics processing unit) prices, only a distant possibility given economic uncertainty in Europe, MKM analyst Ian Ing wrote in his research report.Nvidia stock was flat in early afternoon trading in the stock market today, while Advanced Micro Devices stock was down 1.5%. Both are in IBD's Electronic-Semiconductor Fabless Group, which is up 11% this year.GPU pricing trends have been "benign ... compared to historical declines of high-single-digits," Ing wrote.He added: "This suggests that both Nvidia and Advanced Micro Devices are addressing the fast-growing gaming (total addressable market) that benefits from (an) increased leisure/entertainment mindset vs. traditional consumption."GPUs comprise 20%-25% of Advanced Micro Devices' sales, while gaming comprises 58% of Nvidia's sales, Ing wrote. He says both benefited from a strong Christmas season that saw robust sales for "Star Wars Battlefront," "Call of Duty: Black Ops 3" and eSports gaming.Quarter over quarter, Advanced Micro Devices experienced "modest" price declines in Q3 for its R9 series chips.Nvidia's pricing trends were more favorable, with some higher-end cards up 1%-6% sequentially in Q3, he wrote.To truly bypass AMD, Nvidia will have to slash prices."Advanced Micro Devices and Nvidia have leapfrogged each other in price/performance for years," Ing wrote. "Nvidia leads on performance, and Advanced Micro Devices on price. If Nvidia matches Advanced Micro Devices on price, sales of its graphics cards could increase."Nvidia also faces stout competition in mobile apps processors from Qualcomm (QCOM), Intel (INTC), Samsung and MediaTek, Ing wrote.Ing boosted his price target on Nvidia stock to 39 from 36 and reiterated a buy rating, but he maintained his neutral rating and 3 price target on Advanced Micro Devices stock.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Technology ETFs on Monday reversed early losses, which came as an Apple (AAPL) price target cut put pressure on its stock. The iPhone maker closed down 0.6% on big volume, but shaving a 3% premarket loss.
Exchange-traded funds tracking the S&P 500 index also smartly rebounded from session lows on the stock market today, returning to positive territory for 2015.
However, high-yield bond ETFs fell further as investors eye a key Fed decision on interest rates Wednesday.
Apple Woes
IShares U.S. Technology (IYW), which was down 0.7% intraday, finished with a 0.5% gain.
The diversified tech ETF holds 148 stocks. Apple has the largest portfolio weighting, at 18% of assets.
The Macbook and iPhone maker is also the top holding in several of the largest technology ETFs.
On Sunday night, Morgan Stanley cut its price target on Apple to 143 from 162, citing pressure on iPhone sales from rising international prices and smartphone saturation outside China.
Apple is trading below its 10-week moving average, with a Relative Strength line that's trending back downward.
Microsoft (MSFT) and Facebook (FB), the iShares technology ETF's second- and third-largest holdings, grabbed gains of 2% and 2.5%, respectively.
Qualcomm (QCOM) fell more than 1.3%.
The $2.69 billion iShares U.S. Technology ETF has rallied from its late-September lows but has been range-bound the past couple of months.
It's 3% off its November high, though gaining 6% in the past year.
Technology and consumer staples ETFs advanced the most Monday. Materials trailed.
South Africa and China A-shares ETFs jumped as much as 9% and 4%, respectively, among internationally focused ETFs.
Junk Bonds
SPDR Barclays High Yield Bond (JNK) gave up 0.8% Monday. It yields 6.3%.
IShares iBoxx $ High Yield Corporate Bond (HYG) lost 0.9%. It yields 5.7%.
Both ETFs fell amid mounting concerns about the high-yield debt market.
News of a major junk bond fund preventing withdrawals rattled fixed-income investors Friday.
Gold, Dollar And Oil
Investors drove down prices of less risky assets as stocks bounced back bullishly Monday.
Gold prices eased, while the dollar rose a fraction against other major world currencies.
The largest ETFs backed by physical gold hit a 52-week low this month. They're 18% off their January highs.
A likely interest rate hike this week is weighing on the precious metal, which bears no yield.
Oil prices snapped a six-day losing streak, closing well off session lows. The commodity has been hammered by a global supply glut as OPEC and non-OPEC countries fight for market share.
Intraday, Brent traded below $37 a barrel and U.S. crude below $35, a level last seen in 2009.

Here's a look at how the major exchange-traded funds tracking various asset classes performed today.
Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:

Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Qualcomm (QCOM) got a price target cut Wednesday despite this week's favorable regulatory ruling against a Tesla (TSLA) supplier, while Northrop Grumman (NOC) scored an upgrade, and UnitedHealth Group (UNH) was started with a bullish rating.Cowen cut Qualcomm's price target to 67 from 69 and maintained its outperform rating on the stock. Topeka Capital Markets also cut its price target on the Apple supplier to 52 from 61 and maintained its hold rating.On Monday, the U.S. International Trade Commission sided with Qualcomm and Samsung, upholding an earlier ruling that neither company violated Tesla chipmaker Nvidia's (NVDA) patents on graphics processing chips. Nvidia said it plans to appeal the decision.Qualcomm shares closed up 0.1% on the stock market today. Apple climbed 0.8%, Tesla rose 6% and Nvidia added 0.6%.Defense contractor Northrop Grumman rose 1% after it was upgraded to overweight from neutral by JPMorgan, which also raised its price target on the stock to 212 from 198.Recent consolidation in the defense industry has fueled speculation about whether a Northrop-Boeing (BA) merger might make sense, though the Pentagon is pushing for more power to block defense mergers and preserve competition.Boeing's stock price climbed 1% Wednesday.JPMorgan also upgraded fellow defense aerospace supplier B/E Aerospace (BEAV) to overweight from neutral. B/E shares rose 3.2%.Credit Suisse initiated coverage on a number of managed care stocks. Among the largest players, it started UnitedHealth Group at outperform with a 133 price target, Aetna (AET) at neutral with a 111 price target; and Humana (HUM) at neutral with a 185 price target.UnitedHealth rose 1%, while Aetna climbed 1.6% and Humana added 0.4%.NetApp (NTAP) tacked on 1.3% after it was initiated at underperform by JMP Securities.Solar energy company SolarCity (SCTY) popped more than 34% after its price target was raised to 65 from 55 by Roth Capital, which has a buy rating on the stock, though much of the gain Wednesday was attributed to congressional plans to extend solar tax credits. Follow Vance Cariaga on Twitter: @IBD_VCariaga.

The U.S. International Trade Commission sided with Apple (AAPL) supplier Qualcomm (QCOM) and Samsung on Monday, upholding an earlier ruling that neither violated Tesla (TSLA) chipmaker Nvidia's (NVDA) patents on graphics processing chips.
An Nvidia spokesperson said the company could appeal.

"While today's ruling ends this particular case in the ITC, we remain firm in our belief that our patents are valid and have been infringed and will look to appeal the ITC's decision," Nvidia wrote late Monday on its website.

At least one analyst, in any case, didn't see a big impact. And in afternoon trading Tuesday, Nvidia stock was up more than 1.5%, above 33. Shares are up more than 60% over the past five months, touching a nearly eight-year high of 33.81 on Dec. 4.

Santa Clara, Calif.-based Nvidia filed its initial complaint in September 2014, after private talks between itself and Samsung failed. Nvidia alleged eight patent violations, but later dropped the number to three.

Nvidia most recently sought to ban Samsung smartphones and tablets, including those featuring Qualcomm chips, from sale in the U.S. Samsung argued that Nvidia's claims related to "very specific and narrow aspects of graphics processing units."

The accused products represent 40% of Samsung's Android offerings, including 27% of its smartphone and 18% of its tablet markets, Samsung's attorneys argued in a Nov. 23 filing. Samsung, based in South Korea, estimated that its smaller peers would need six to nine months to fill the gap created by a U.S. import ban on those products.
"A (ban) would leave one dominant MDM (mobile device management), Apple, and would lower competition among other MDMs," they wrote.

But Nvidia noted that the "mobile communication device and tablet market is intensely competitive, very fast-growing and dynamic, (and) Samsung's accused products comprise a relatively small share of the industry," according to a Nov. 23 filing.
First Ruling In October
In its filing late Monday, the trade agency upheld a judge's determination in October, siding with Samsung and Qualcomm.
On Tuesday, RBC Capital analyst Mitch Steves maintained his 32 price target and sector perform rating on Nvidia stock.

"The patent ruling removes a potential 'call option' or upside to Nvidia licensing/royalty revenue, (but) the announcement does not negatively impact our numbers," he wrote. "Importantly, we continue to view Nvidia's automotive and virtual reality opportunity as robust."
Nvidia doesn't depend on licensing in its business model, Nvidia CEO Jen-Hsun Huang told investors during the company's November Q3 earnings conference call.
On that point, Steves noted that a $66 million quarterly royalty from Intel (INTC) expires in 2017.

"Other parts of Nvidia's business have grown in excess of the flat royalty business over the past three years," he wrote. "When the royalties go away, the impact could be smaller, as Nvidia could grow in spite of the loss in royalties."

At the end of every year, business journalists and Wall Street analysts sit down and write up their boldest predictions for mergers and acquisitions in the coming year. And like the people shown riding hoverboards in YouTube videos, they're likely to fall on their butts.Tech M&A predictions are often wrong because they're born out of wishful thinking. They ignore market realities, CEO personalities and other factors that can make such deals tough to pull off.But they're fun to consider. So with that in mind, here's a roundup of the boldest predictions for tech company mergers and acquisitions in 2016.Apple Buys Tesla MotorsApple (AAPL) is rumored to be working on an electric car and it could "dramatically accelerate" those efforts if it bought Tesla Motors (TSLA), says Aaron Task, digital editor at Fortune magazine."With over $200 billion cash on hand, the iPhone maker has more than ample resources to absorb the purchase, especially now that some of the bloom has come off Tesla's once-rosy stock," Task wrote. "In addition to its automobile know-how, Apple gets access to Tesla's battery, which CEO Elon Musk claims can help change 'the entire energy infrastructure of the world.'"Plus, Musk would be a worthy heir to Apple co-founder Steve Jobs and would be ideally suited to be Apple's futurist, chief technologist and CEO-in-waiting, Task said.AT&T Buys YahooWeb giant Yahoo (YHOO) will be sold to telecom powerhouse AT&T (T), mirroring Verizon's (VZ) acquisition of AOL earlier in the year, predicts Chris Ciaccia, technology editor at TheStreet."Yahoo's purchase of BrightRoll could help AT&T with its reported streaming service, as it seeks to have ads inserted into it," Ciaccia wrote. "There are other players for Yahoo, like a media company or a private equity firm, but AT&T just makes too much sense to me."GoPro Sold To Larger Tech FirmWith GoPro's (GPRO) stock depressed, a larger technology firm is likely to sweep in and buy the maker of action cameras, according to Orange Peel Investments."With zero debt and $513 million in cash, the company has a clean slate for an LBO to come in, whisk them off their feet and take advantage of the company's ability to lever," the firm said in a post on Seeking Alpha. "The obvious acquiring party in this transaction would be a larger technology or electronics outfit, such as an Apple, Samsung or Microsoft (MSFT). They could use the company's brand in a way similar to how Apple is using Beats. They could continue to have the brand name separate from the core brand and then eventually vertically integrate the two companies for future projects."Comcast Will Try To Buy NetflixIn a prediction out of left field, Yahoo Tech editor Dan Tynan believes cable giant Comcast (CMCSA) will try to acquire Internet TV service Netflix (NFLX) or possibly vice versa."Whether or not you're a cord-cutter, streaming media is the future of entertainment — and nobody streams bigger than Netflix, which accounted for nearly 40% of all Internet traffic last year. Since Big Cable can't beat the streamers at this game, the only thing left is for it to join them by acquisition," Tynan wrote. "Comcast ($192 billion valuation) and Netflix ($42 billion) are the most logical candidates for an arranged marriage. While it stands to reason that the larger company will swallow the smaller one, it's not inconceivable that the reverse will happen — not unlike AOL's acquisition of Time Warner 15 years ago, but perhaps with better results."Apple Buys A Movie StudioVariety magazine's writers and editors are predicting a lot of M&A activity in Hollywood in 2016. Most notably, they think Apple will buy a movie studio to support its goals for a subscription Internet video service."With more than $200 billion in cash on hand, the Cupertino colossus is poised to rewrite the rules of the media game," the Variety staff wrote. "Viacom (VIAB) or HBO might seem the likeliest prey, but Sony (SNE) is a juicier target, given the mix of hardware and programming under its hood."Variety thinks Chinese Internet giant Alibaba Group (BABA) also is interested in buying a Hollywood player. Possible targets for Alibaba include Viacom, CBS (CBS), Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF) and DreamWorks Animation.However, John Malone is most likely to snap up Lions Gate and merge it with cable channel Starz (STRZA), Variety said.Time Warner (TWX), parent of HBO and Warner Bros., could become an M&A target in 2016, Variety said. One likely bidder would be 21st Century Fox (FOXA), the trade paper said.Intel Or Qualcomm Buys InvenSenseU.K.-based research firm CCS Insight makes a lot of annual tech industry predictions, including some about mergers and acquisitions.It predicts that Intel (INTC) or Qualcomm (QCOM) will acquire InvenSense (INVN) in 2016."The acquisition follows a large fall in the market capitalization of InvenSense in the second half of 2015," CCS Insight said in a report. "Its purchaser recognizes the opportunity to snap up InvenSense's assets in sensor technology. As sensors take on greater importance in the Internet of Things and wearable devices, the buyer integrates InvenSense's technology into a wider range of semiconductors."CCS Insight also predicts that Samsung will acquire chipmaker GlobalFoundries by 2017."GlobalFoundries is currently struggling to compete against Intel, Samsung and TSMC (TSM)," it said. "Chip manufacturing becomes increasingly capital- and scale-intensive, with huge pressure on capacity as demand balloons for silicon for the Internet of Things. Samsung's foundry business accounts for a growing proportion of the company's profit, and the acquisition helps cement Samsung's position in this area."Dish Network Gets MarriedDish Network (DISH) will merge with someone in 2016, says Phillip Swann, president of TVPredictions.com."The nation's second-largest satellite TV service needs help to stay competitive, and that assistance can only come from a merger," Swann wrote. Possible merger partners include T-Mobile (TMUS), Verizon, Amazon.com (AMZN) and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google."Out of full disclosure, I have predicted in the past that Dish will merge with someone, and it hasn't happened yet," Swann said. "But this time, well, this time I really think it will happen."RELATED:Apple 2016 Predictions: Acquisitions, Accessories.Cloud, Virtual Reality Among Top Tech Trends For 2016.

Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT) spent more on stock buybacks than any other companies, both in the third quarter and in the trailing 12 months. Apple spent $15.3 billion on stock buybacks in Q3, followed by Microsoft at $4 billion, according to data collected by FactSet Research. Companies in the S&P 500 spent a total of $156 billion on share…

A Deutsche Bank analyst's October prediction that Micron Technology (MU) will face two "choppy" quarters may come to fruition — the No. 5 chipmaker is expected late Tuesday to report a 75% year-over-year drop in earnings.Analyst Sidney Ho, however, said Micron could be helped by cost tailwinds and potential capital expenditure cuts by competing memory suppliers. Micron stock is down 60% for the year.For its fiscal Q1 ended early this month, Micron is expected to report 23 cents earnings per share ex items on $3.46 billion in sales, down 75% and 24%, respectively, vs. the year-earlier quarter.Three months ago, Micron guided to $3.35 billion to $3.6 billion in sales and 20-26 cents EPS minus items.Micron stock fell 2.7% on Monday, after the chipmaker announced the $3.2 billion deal to acquire Taiwan chipmaker Inotera Memories. But Micron rose 2% for the week, including rising a fraction on Friday.And at least six analysts reiterated buy ratings on Micron stock this week following the Inotera announcement.Per the agreement, Micron will pay 30 New Taiwan dollars, or 92 cents, per Inotera share. Micron already owns 33% of Inotera and the two companies have been memory chip partners for seven years.The acquisition is expected to be immediately accretive to Micron's EPS, free cash flow, gross margins and EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization). The companies have 60 days to terminate the agreement.M&As Breach $100 Bil MarkMicron's $3.2 billion Inotera acquisition is just a drop in the $100 billion-plus chip industry M&A bucket for 2015. Big deals included Apple (AAPL) supplier Avago's (AVGO) $37 billion offer for Broadcom and the $19 billion marriage between SanDisk (SNDK) and Western Digital (WDC).Analysts expect the M&A fever to continue into 2016 as the semiconductor industry faces slowing organic growth, rising costs and a limp global economy. Complicating the matter: China wants in on the action and Tsinghua Unigroup has pledged $47 billion to leapfrog Qualcomm (QCOM) to become the No. 3 chipmaker.The Tsinghua push is part of a larger effort by the Chinese government to ease reliance on foreign chips, in part to reduce cybersnooping concerns. Groups in Shanghai and Beijing are making similar efforts, pulling from a $100 billion, government-sponsored pool.This year, Tsinghua Unigroup reportedly made an unsolicited $23 billion bid for Micron. U.S. regulations likely would have stopped the theoretical merger and the offer seems to have fallen off the map.As M&A activity hits new fever pitches in 2016, analysts see smaller chip companies Xilinx (XLNX), Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM) and Cavium (CAVM) as possible takeover candidates.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Altera (ALTR) stock hit a fresh 15-year high Monday after the Chinese Ministry of Commerce approved its acquisition by No. 1 chipmaker Intel (INTC) — the final regulatory obstacle to the transaction. The $16.7 billion acquisition, at about $54 a share, is expected to close Dec. 28, according to 8K filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. In morning…

Early on the stock market today, Mellanox was up fractionally ahead of its scheduled fiscal Q3 earnings release Wednesday. Stocks ended with modest losses in mixed volume Thursday.The S&P 500 lost 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.3% and the Nasdaq eased less than 0.1%. Preliminary data showed NYSE volume falling slightly from Tuesday's levels. Nasdaq volume rose a bit in the stock market today.Facebook (FB) shares rose after hours on better-than-expected quarterly results. EPS was 57 cents vs. estimates of 52 cents.In testimony in front of the House Financial Services Committee, Fed Chair Janet Yellen said a rate hike at the December meeting is a "live possibility." According to CME Group FedWatch, the odds of a rate hike at the December meeting have risen to 56%. Around the time of the last Fed meeting in late October, odds were around 33%.The yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose 2 basis points to 2.23%. The dollar rallied against other currencies and the euro hit a three-month low.Among the day's big gainers, Tesla (TSLA) soared 11% despite reporting a wider-than-expected loss of 58 cents a share. Investors focused instead on comments from Tesla that orders are accelerating for its Model S sedan and its luxury crossover Model X.IBD Sector Leaders Paycom Software (PAYC) and Fleetmatics (FLTX) turned in solid performances. Paycom vaulted 17% on news quarterly profit jumped 60% to 8 cents a share. Sales rose 51% to $55.3 million. The provider of cloud-based, workforce management software also offered up bullish Q4 revenue guidance. Shares of Fleetmatics gained 7.5%, also on strong earnings.Reports are also due from HubSpot (HUBS), Epam Systems (EPAM) and Qualcomm (QCOM).At the New York Mercantile Exchange, December crude oil futures slumped $1.58, or 3.3%, to $46.32 a barrel after U.S. government data showed that crude inventories rose for the sixth straight week.Follow Ken Shreve on Twitter: @IBD_KShreve and on Facebook

Apple (AAPL) supplier NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) muscled by completing its $12 billion acquisition of smaller peer Freescale Semiconductor, making it No. 5 by market value in IBD's 46-company Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group.
With a $20.4 billion market cap, NXP trails only Qualcomm (QCOM), Avago Technologies (AVGO), Broadcom (BRCM) — all fellow Apple suppliers — and ARM Holdings (ARMH) .

In late-afternoon trading on the stock market today, NXP stock was up nearly 2%, near 88. Freescale stock closed down 1.5%, at 36.53, on Monday, its last day of trading on the NYSE. NXP stock fell 4.6% on Monday.
The companies announced the closing of their deal on Monday. The merger was announced in March, heralding a record-busting year for chip industry M&As.
In May, Avago agreed to buy Broadcom for $37 billion. A month later, Intel (INTC) announced that it had inked a $16.7 billion deal to buy Altera (ALTR) .
On a single day in October, Western Digital (WDC) agreed to buy SanDisk (SNDK) for $19 billion, and chip gear maker Lam Research (LRCX) put up a $10.6 billion bid for rival KLA-Tencor (KLAC).

Last month, On Semiconductor (ON) agreed to buy Fairchild Semiconductor (FCS) for $2.4 billion. Meanwhile, Microsemi (MSCC) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) battled it out for PMC-Sierra (PMCS) for over a month before Microsemi won with a $2.5 billion offer.
Combined, NXP and Freescale expect $10 billion in annual sales. The merged company has 45,000 employees — including 11,000 engineers — and 9,000 patent families, according to an NXP overview.
NXP says that it expects to be No. 1 in communications processors, secure identification, broad-based microcontrollers, radio-frequency transistors, automotive chips and small-signal discretes.
In 2020, NXP aims to ship 40 billion connected devices in areas such as secure ID and mobile transactions.

Together, NXP and Freescale plan to lead the industry in chips for payment cards, point-of-sale terminals, transport ticketing, closed loop payment and mobile transactions, according to the company's plan.

Today, "90% of auto innovation" is within electronics, according to NXP. The company says that it plans to lead the industry in terms of infotainment, vehicle networking, body, safety and secure access.

China's Tsinghua Unigroup has Apple (AAPL) supplier Qualcomm (QCOM) in its sights, planning to invest $47 billion over the next five years to leapfrog Qualcomm and become the world's No. 3 chipmaker.
And Tsinghua's ambitions could find it swallowing up smaller chipmakers such as Maxim Integrated (MXIM), Micron Technology (MU) and Xilinx (XLNX).

The state-owned investment group must outplay U.S. companies scrambling amid frenzied chip sector M&A froth that's busted records in 2015. But its $47 billion strongbox makes battles winnable, Alex Lidow, CEO of privately held power management device maker Efficient Power Conversion, told IBD.

"With a $47 billion war chest, they can do some serious stuff," Lidow said. "You've got companies like Maxim and Xilinx and Micron that are (acquisitions) that would give them immediate, significant market presence in big sectors."
With its resources, Tsinghua "could buy all of them," Lidow said.
Flipping The Paradigm

China plans to flip a longstanding paradigm. The country consumes roughly half the world's $350 billion in chips, but only accounts for 2.5% of the sector's revenue, according to Nanochip Fab Solutions . Chips, in fact, are China's biggest import, says Nanochip.
In June 2014, the government pledged to curb China's reliance on foreign semiconductors.

By 2020, China aims to generate 350 billion yuan ($55 billion) in domestic chip revenue, seeking a compound annual growth rate of 20%. No more than 10 years later, the country wants a top-tier semiconductor company. Thus, the National Semiconductor Industry Investment Fund was born.

Tsinghua is one of 16 shareholders of the fund — a $100 billion pot of which 60% will be directed toward manufacturing acquisitions, according to Semi.org. Groups in Shanghai and Beijing, too, have planned hefty chip investments.

But Tsinghua has been particularly vocal about its goal. Last month, Chairman Zhao Weiguo told Reuters the group will invest $47 billion over five years to become the world's No. 3 chipmaker, behind No. 1 Intel (INTC) and Samsung.
"If you can't be the top-three giant, it will be very hard to develop your business in the chip industry," he told Reuters. "The next five years is key. ... there is an enormous market there."

Intel and Samsung Electronics have market valued near $164 billion and $160 billion, respectively. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSM) follows in value at $118 billion, but it's a manufacturer that doesn't design its own chips, so it's in a little bit of a different market, with thinner profit margins. Qualcomm is No. 4 in chip company market value, near $73 billion.

"Qualcomm is most at risk because they are already seeing their dominant position in cellphones being challenged, with Samsung and Apple and in the Chinese smartphone market," Lidow said. "They are most vulnerable, for sure."
Tangling With U.S. Government

Tsinghua already has invested billions in chip acquisitions, buying China chipmakers Spreadtrum Communications for $1.8 billion and RDA Microelectronics for $900 million in 2013 and 2014. But getting its hands on a U.S. company is much more difficult, since the U.S. aims to protect its chip industry trade secrets and intellectual property.

In August, Tsinghua made an unsolicited $23 billion bid for Boise, Idaho-based Micron, showing its serious interest in flash memory technology. Wall Street scoffed, saying the U.S. Department of Defense would block that transaction. And the informal bid seemingly has gone nowhere.

"That's one of the reasons Chinese fabs aren't up to par with U.S. fabs, because they're somewhat restricted as to the technology they have access to," Semiconductor Advisors analyst Robert Maire told IBD.

The Bureau of Industry and Security tightly controls exports to protect national security and the U.S. economy. Semiconductors are a heavily regulated resource, appearing 41 times on the Bureau's controlled list.
But it's possible Tsinghua found a loophole.

Last month, Tsinghua invested $3.8 billion in Irvine, Calif.-based Western Digital (WDC), a month after Western Digital agreed to buy Milpitas, Calif.-based flash chip maker SanDisk (SNDK) for $19 billion.
By investing in Western Digital, Tsinghua got itself that much closer to U.S. chip patents, Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan told IBD.
"Tsinghua put in $3.8 billion into Western Digital so they would have SanDisk technology," he said.

China could also make a play for Milpitas, Calif.-based GlobalFoundries, the manufacturing spinoff of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) with fabs in Singapore, Germany and the U.S. Oil-rich Abu Dhabi owns the company and might be looking for a buyer.
To compete with the mature U.S. semiconductor market, Tsinghua "needs to bulk up," Maire said. Fabs such as GlobalFoundries and Taiwan Semiconductor carry significant heft.

"With Micron, U.S. legislators would never let that go through," he said. "But (Tsinghua) could get around (U.S. regulations) and get around the technological hurdles by cutting a deal with GlobalFoundries.
"I wouldn't call it subterfuge, but it would be an interesting back door for China to get its hands on crucial U.S. semiconductor technology."
'Mattson And Chinese Dragon'
Chinese involvement aside, 2015 marked a record M&A year for the rapidly consolidating semiconductor industry. The trend looks to continue in 2016, Lidow said.

"Just about any of the second- and third-tier semiconductors are probably going to be involved in M&A activity over the next couple of years — Cypress Semiconductor (CY), Micron, GlobalFoundries, Maxim, Xilinx," he said.
Maire also cites Axcelis Technologies (ACLS), Rudolph Technologies (RTEC), Nanometrics (NANO), Nova Measuring (NVMI) and Ultratech (UTEK) as potential acquisition targets.

Chip giants Texas Instruments (TXN), Intel and Samsung are safe — for the time being, Lidow said. He estimates it would take a Chinese company five years after a major acquisition to make any dominant inroads in the semiconductor world.

Beijing-based E-Town Dragon Semiconductor Industry Investment Center, not Tsinghua, has already begun its efforts on that cycle, this month announcing an agreement to acquire Mattson Technology (MTSN), a maker of chip-manufacturing gear based in Fremont, Calif., for $12.2 million.

Acquiring Mattson is just a drop in the "proverbial bucket," Maire wrote in a research report. E-Town's plans remain veiled, but regulators will likely approve the acquisition, as "Mattson has no advanced technology the U.S. government would be concerned about," he wrote.

"It will be an interesting test as this is the first Chinese acquisition of a U.S. semiconductor company," Maire wrote. But "this is not a very bold start, buying the worst equipment company as compared to the very bold bid by the Chinese to buy Micron."
He added: "Even if the Micron bid was doomed from the start, it was certainly headline grabbing."

Stocks eased out of narrow opening gains and into mixed trade Wednesday, as earnings and economic news pushed and pulled on early action.
The Dow held on to a 0.5% advance. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 backed off 0.1% apiece.
Volume also opened on a mixed note, rising 19% on the Nasdaq but slipping 3% on the NYSE, relative to trade at the same time Tuesday.

The stock market today launched on news that private-sector employers added 182,00 new workers in October, down from September's pace but slightly better than expected. The U.S. trade deficit slimmed more than expected in September, to $40.8 billion — its lowest level in seven months.

Researcher Markit reported the U.S. services sector cooled only slightly in October, with its Purchasing Managers' Index easing to 54.8 — in line with consensus expectations. The Institute for Supply Management's October services index went the other direction, punching up to 59.1 vs. a 56.9 tally for September. Economists' consensus had projected a slight dip to 56.7.
Fed Chair Janet Yellen was scheduled to testify before the House Committee on Financial Services at 10 a.m. ET.

Oil prices shed early gains, with West Texas Intermediate backing down a fraction to below $48 a barrel ahead of the Energy Information Administration's weekly inventories report, expected at 10:30 a.m.
The Dow opened with 25 of its 30 issues moving higher. Wal-Mart (WMT) led the upside with a 1% gain.

Gas producer Range Resources (RRC) topped the S&P 500, spiking 9% at the start of trade. Citigroup upgraded the stock to buy from neutral. CBS (CBS) punched up 4% after reporting solid Q3 results late Tuesday.
At the low end of the S&P 500, medical software developer Cerner (CERN) shed 7%. The Kansas City, Mo.-company reported a Q3 earnings miss after Tuesday's close.

On the IBD 50 list, Paycom Software (PAYC) thrashed out a 17% gain, forcefully retaking a 41.68 buy point and spiking to new highs. The provider of cloud-based human capital services late Tuesday reported third-quarter results and guidance above consensus expectations.

Other early risers on the IBD 50 list included Dycom (DY) and LGI Homes (LGIH), up more than 2% each. The gain put Dycom 4% above an 80.95 buy point in a flat base. LGI is in buying range as it rebounds from a test of 10-week support.

Cognizant (CTSH) notched the group's worst loss, down a bit less than 4% after its third-quarter report just met consensus projections. The loss dragged shares back below a 68.06 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Stocks fell to session lows in afternoon trading Wednesday as investors parsed a speech by Fed chief Janet Yellen that was more hawkish than dovish.The S&P 500 fell 0.9%, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.7% and the Nasdaq eased 0.4%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking close to Tuesday's levels in the stock market today.In a speech in front of the Economic Club of Washington, D.C., Fed chief Janet Yellen sounded optimistic about the economy. The tone of the speech seemed to be prepping the market for a rate hike at the Dec. 15-16 meeting. Yellen testifies in front of Congress on Thursday.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures were down $1.77, or 4.2%, to $40.08 a barrel on news that U.S. crude supplies rose for the 10th straight week. OPEC meets Friday in Vienna.Qualcomm (QCOM) and Yahoo (YHOO) buoyed the Nasdaq. Qualcomm jumped 5.7% after signing a patent license agreement with Chinese phone maker Xiaomi. Yahoo, meanwhile, added 5.3% on reports that the company might be considering selling its core Internet business. Yahoo still has a 15% stake in Alibaba (BABA).Airlines outperformed after Delta Air Lines (DAL) reported a surprise gain in monthly per passenger revenue in November. Shares of Delta rose nearly 2%. IBD 50 name Hawaiian Holdings (HA) was another big gainer in the group, rising 3.5%.Retailers and apparel makers will make a showing in a busy after-hours session Wednesday, with quarterly reports due from PVH (PVH), American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) and Aeropostale (ARO), as well as from chipmaker Avago Technologies (AVGO).Follow Ken Shreve on Twitter: @IBD_KShreve and on Facebook.

Stock futures trudged toward a mixed open Wednesday, ahead of a busy day of commentary and data from the Federal Reserve. The Nasdaq stood out with a 4.6-point gain, while Dow futures traded 18.4 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures and Russell 200 futures were down a fraction apiece.The stock market today will get a strong dose of Fed speak, with Fed Chief Janet Yellen scheduled for two speeches during trading hours. Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank President Dennis Lockhart, San Francisco Federal Reserve President John Williams and Fed board Governor Daniel Tarullo also are lined up for speaking engagements before the end of the day.There's more: The Fed's December Beige Book report is due out at 2 p.m. Eastern time. Analysts and investors are looking for any hint of how the Fed will decide to proceed in its Dec. 16 rate policy decision.Private, nonfarm employers in the U.S. added 217,000 workers in November, according to the ADP national employment report. The new hires were fairly evenly divided between small, midsize and larger companies, the report said, but service-sector employers were far more active than manufacturers, accounting for 204,000 of the new jobs.The Labor Department revised its estimate of productivity among workers in the third quarter upward to a 2.2% increase vs. earlier estimates of a 1.6% gain. The revision was in line with consensus expectations and leaves the estimate still below Q2's 3.5% increase, but ahead of a 1.1% decline in Q1.Unit labor costs were more of a surprise, revised upward to a 1.8% increase — above the department's initial 1.4% estimate and counter to forecasts for a revision lower to a 0.9% gain.Oil prices continue to bob in their recent range, down 1% this morning, but with West Texas Intermediate still within its $41 to $43 per barrel box and Brent crude fluctuating between $43 and $45. The Energy Information Administration releases its weekly oil inventories data at 10:30 a.m.In stocks, Nike (NKE) again showed the Dow's largest decline, down 0.7%. Houston-based Columbia Pipeline (CPGX) dropped 8%, the worst hit among S&P 500 stocks, after announcing late Monday a 51 million share offering in order to fund its 2016 capital expenditures.Yahoo (YHOO) and Qualcomm (QCOM) pulled up the Nasdaq 100, rising more than 3% each in premarket trade.Yahoo jumped after news reports said its board will enter discussions today as to whether the company should sell its core Internet business or finalize the spinoff of its interest in Alibaba (BABA). The spinoff of China-based diversified Internet giant Alibaba, in which Yahoo holds a 15% stake, has been discussed for some time.The separation of the core Internet business is a move urged in a November letter from hedge fund Starboard Value, which called itself a "significant shareholder" of Yahoo. The Wall Street Journal named Japan's SoftBank as an interested potential buyer of Yahoo's Internet business. Yahoo shares have been retaking some ground since marking a low in early October, but the stock remains 36% below its year-ago high.Qualcomm surged on news of its deal to allow China-based mobile device maker Xiaomi to produce 3G and 4G cell phones using Qualcomm patents. Qualcomm shares tumbled 18% in November, sending the stock to new lows in its 19-month correction.The stable of IBD 50 and Your Weekly Review names was quiet for a second day, with no stocks in the groups rising or falling as much as 1% ahead of the start of regular trade. LGI Homes (LGIH) and Natus Medical (BABY) had scored some of the best gains on the two lists on Tuesday, both rising to new highs.

Stocks wobbled in and out of gains and losses early Wednesday, as company news and mixed economic reports powered the bulk of early trade.The Nasdaq held steady with a 0.2% gain. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each logged 0.1% declines. The small-cap Russell 2000 clung to a fractional gain.Volume was mixed at the start of trade, up 19% on the Nasdaq and 13% lower on the NYSE, vs. activity at the same time Tuesday.Yahoo (YHOO) and Qualcomm (QCOM) were the opening stories in the stock market today, with Qualcomm up 8% on a patent royalty deal in China and Yahoo jumping 4% on news that it may spin off not one, but two units into separately traded entities.A heavy lineup of speeches form Federal Reserve officials, including two speeches from Chief Janet Yellen, could figure in the day's trade as investors attempt to divine how the central bank will proceed with a possible policy shift at its Dec. 15-16 meeting. The Fed's beige book report for December is due out at 2 p.m. ET.Private employers added 217,000 workers in November, according to the ADP national employment report. Economists had forecast 183,000 added jobs. Nearly all of the hirings were among service sector employers.Oil prices swung nearly 2% lower, but with West Texas Intermediate and Brent crude holding within their recent trading ranges, ahead of the Energy Information Administration's weekly stockpiles report, due out at 10:30 a.m.Logistics leader C.H. Robinson (CHRW) dived almost 7%, the worst showing among S&P 500 stocks.Airlines staged an early rally after Delta Air Lines (DAL) reported a surprise gain in monthly per passenger revenue in November. Delta, United Continental (UAL) and American Airlines (AAL) were all up nearly 3%. JetBlue (JBLU), Southwest Airlines (LUV) and Ryanair (RYAAY) gained 2% apiece.Among IBD 50 stocks, Hawaiian (HA) jumped 4%, Alaska Air (AAL) took a 1% gain.Hawaiian's gain left shares just below its Nov. 6 high as the stock works on the fourth week in a flat consolidation. The airline triggered an eight-week hold rule on Oct. 19, rising more than 20% above a 25.69 buy point in less than two weeks.IBD 50 peer AMN Healthcare Services (AHS) popped almost 3% at the open. The medical staffing agency is up 32% from a late October low, climbing the right side of a deep, two-month consolidation.Retailers and apparel makers will make a showing in a busy after-hours session Wednesday, with quarterly reports due out from PVH (PVH), American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) and Aeropostale (ARO), as well as from chipmaker Avago Technologies (AVGO).Overseas, Europe's markets were a bit more broadly mixed near midday than U.S. stocks, ahead of the European Central Bank's key policy vote due out there Thursday. China's markets rose, with the Shanghai Composite jumping 2.3% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index ending up 0.4%.

CEO Moshe Gavrielov said Xilinx was already climbing out of its "trough." "I don't see us returning to that previous peak, which I believe was in the March 2014 quarter,…
As the PC market slowly stabilizes, No. 1 chipmaker Intel (INTC) has "circled its wagons around the golden goose" — its data center group — Semiconductor Advisors analyst Robert Maire said Wednesday.

Sales of chips for data center servers remain a key growth area for Santa Clara, Calif.-based Intel, though CFO Stacy Smith guided 2015 data center revenue down to low-double-digit growth from the prior outlook of 15% growth, in the company's earnings conference call with analysts late Tuesday.
Intel's Q3 EPS and revenue, however, beat views, and its Q4 revenue outlook was in line. Intel was up a fraction in midday trading in the stock market today, near 32.
At least three investment banks hiked their price target on Intel stock after the earnings report.
There are signs the PC market is stabilizing, Intel CEO Brian Krzanich told analysts on the call, but he said the recovery wouldn't be immediate, given economic headwinds worldwide.
Intel's Q3 revenue was down a small fraction vs. Q3 2014, helped by higher notebook and desktop pricing, Krzanich said.

"In a time period where PC units are down in high single digits at the TAM (total addressable market) level, we still get enough growth from the data center and the memory business and the Internet of Things to pretty much tread water in terms of revenue growth," he said.
Intel Smartphone Market
For 2016, Intel is focused on expanding its smartphone modem offerings in direct competition with Qualcomm (QCOM), Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan wrote in a research report.
Qualcomm, in conjunction with Mellanox (MLNX) and Xilinx (XLNX), also recently introduced a data center system-on-a-chip that will compete with Intel and others.

In another area, should Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSM) cut their 2016 capital expenditures, Intel's 10-nanometer chip "stands a good chance of getting the foundry business from Apple (AAPL)," Sundararajan wrote.
Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor are providing processor chips for Apple's iPhone 6S and 6S Plus.
The current high end of chip manufacturing is 14 nm, which basically refers to the width of the circuitry etching on silicon. The next evolution will be 10 nm.
Intel, though, is working to ramp its 14 nm production in Ireland, Maire wrote in a research report. Higher expenses and likely poor yield show the process is "still flaky," he wrote.
"If Intel still doesn't have 14 nm nailed and Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor are pumping out similar geometries, we may be back to a closer race to 10 nm," he wrote.
Intel Enters 'Attack Mode'
Intel shifted $400 million in capital expenditures to 2016 to reconfigure a chipmaking tool in order to boost output, Krzanich said on Tuesday's call.
Sundararajan and Maire theorized that Intel chip-manufacturing partners ASML Holding (ASML) or KLA-Tencor (KLAC) own the tool. For 2015, Intel cut its capex to $7.3 billion from $7.7 billion.
That capex increase for 2016 "means Intel is in attack mode," Sundararajan wrote.
Sundararajan upgraded Intel stock to buy and boosted his price target to 40. Northland Securities hiked its price target to 39 from 37.50, and RBC raised its target to 34 from 33.
MKM analyst Ian Ing reiterated a buy rating and a 40 price target for Intel stock.

Ing sees Intel's future in the data center market, where its new 3D XPoint chip, which Intel is developing in conjunction with Micron (MU), could provide "significant additional upside not reflected in present growth targets."

No. 1 chipmaker Intel (INTC) won't overtake Apple (AAPL) mobile chip supplier Qualcomm (QCOM) and Sony (SNE) supplier MediaTek in the mobile industry, but the company has diversified enough to survive lingering hunger pangs within the weak PC industry, one analyst said Friday.MKM analyst Ian Ing reiterated his 40 price target and buy rating on Intel stock, after the chip leader hosted its annual analyst day on Thursday. At least six analysts reiterated buy ratings on Intel stock this week.In afternoon trading in the stock market today, Intel shares were up nearly 1.5%, near 35, and earlier touched an 11-month high of 35.29.2016 Guidance Meets ForecastsIntel's overall message was upbeat Thursday, Ing wrote in a research report.Gross profit margins of 60%-64% are expected to be flat year over year, and Intel guided to capital expenditures of $10 billion, plus or minus $500 million, for 2016, Ing wrote.The company sees 2016 earnings per share ex items of $2.35, at the midpoint of its range, near the $2.36 consensus of 47 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, Credit Suisse analyst John Pitzer wrote in a research report.Intel CEO Brian Krzanich sees the data center, Internet of Things and tech development groups as growth vehicles, Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan wrote in a report, while PC chips remain solid."Brian Krzanich described the client computing group as the engine on which progress in the rest of the company rests," Sundararajan wrote. "He views data center, Internet of Things and the memory business as growth vehicles for Intel."Pitzer and Sundararajan both have a 40 price target on Intel stock. Pitzer rates Intel stock outperform, while Sundararajan rates it buy.Diversifying Despite PC ComebackPCs are making something of a comeback as the installed base ages and customers mull upgrading to Microsoft's (MSFT) new Windows 10 operating system, Ing wrote. Wintel — PCs running on Windows software and Intel chips — has long been the industry standard.Average PC sales prices are on the rise "as attractive new form factors are launched," Ing said.Aside from the PC stabilization, Intel has smartly diversified its portfolio, Pitzer wrote. In 2016, 40% of revenue will stem from non-PC businesses, up from 34% four years ago, at the PC field's peak.In memory, Intel will start producing 3D X-Point and 10-nanometer chips in 2016. Intel also put 7-nanometer chips "onto the chart" on Thursday, Ing wrote.But Ing can't fathom why Intel continues to try to claw its way into the mobile industry."We didn't hear a credible story on why Intel needs to stay in mobile and how it will displace leading incumbents (Qualcomm and MediaTek)," he wrote. "Intel's rationale that LTE modems help support future IoT and 5G infrastructure do not seem like a necessity."Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

No. 1 chipmaker Intel delivered a nickel beat late Tuesday to Wall Street's Q3 earnings-per-share forecast, though EPS was down 3% from the year-earlier quarter. Sales for the quarter ended Sept. 26 fell, but by just a fraction, also beating analysts' views.
The company's revenue forecast for the current quarter was roughly in line, but the company disappointed with its outlook for its faster-growing data-center and Internet of Things businesses.
Intel (INTC) stock lost 2.5% in after-hours trading following the earnings release. Intel stock fell a fraction in the regular session, to 32.04, and it's down 13% for the year.
For Q3, Intel reported 64 cents EPS on $14.5 billion in revenue vs. 59 cents and $14.6 billion in Q3 2014. Analysts had modeled EPS of 59 cents and $14.22 billion in sales.

The Santa Clara, Calif., company said it expects revenue this quarter of $14.3 billion to $15.3 billion, with a midpoint just shy of the $14.83 billion that analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected. At the midpoint, sales would be up just 0.5% from Q4 2014, but that would be its best showing in four quarters.
Data Center Thrives

Sales of chips for servers and other data-center gear, as well as chips for Internet of Things devices and memory chips, accounted for 40% of Intel's Q3 revenue and offset a continued decline in PC-chip sales and macroeconomic weakness, Intel CFO Stacy Smith said in an earnings conference call with analysts.

Data Center and IoT sales rose 12% and 10% year-over-year, respectively. For the year, however, Smith now says Intel expects "low double-digit growth" in data centers, where the company earlier had forecast 15% growth.
"We expect memory to grow at a fast pace," he said. "Data center and the Internet of Things will also be strong ... but slower."
Data-center customers typically don't make large purchases in Q4, Smith said.
"It's their selling season, so they don't want to disrupt their seasons," he said. "There's always lumpiness quarter to quarter."
Smith said that eventually he expects the company's cloud products to outweigh any weaknesses.

Before the earnings release, MKM analyst Ian Ing and Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan both said they were confident Intel would beat its own guidance, despite weak PC DRAM (dynamic random-access memory) sales and China's slowing economy.

Intel will likely face some data-center competition from Qualcomm (QCOM), which recently allied itself with Mellanox Technologies (MLNX) and Xilinx (XLNX) to create an ARM-based, data-center-on-a-chip system, Sundararajan wrote in a recent research report.
Qualcomm is likely targeting big server customers such as Google (GOOG), Amazon (AMZN), Facebook (FB), Microsoft (MSFT), Alibaba (BABA) and Baidu (BIDU), Sundararajan said.
Sundararajan rates Intel stock a hold, with a price target of 30.
CEO: PCs Stabilizing

CEO Brian Krzanich said on the call that he sees signs of the PC market stabilizing, boosted by the launches of Microsoft's newest computer operating system, Windows 10, and Intel's sixth-generation core processor. Intel is the biggest chipmaker by virtue of its longtime dominance in PC chips.
Intel will also benefit from its 3D XPoint chip launch which, Smith says, is poised to "interrupt the industry." Intel and Micron (MU) are jointly developing this new type of memory chip.

Smith said he is particularly excited about possibilities in the gaming and notebook markets. More expensive notebook and desktop offerings helped drive revenue in Q3, he said.No. 1 chipmaker Intel delivered a nickel beat late Tuesday to Wall Street's Q3 earnings-per-share forecast, though EPS was down 3% from the year-earlier quarter. MasterCard (MA) reported higher-than-expected profit and emphasized its digital innovations as mobile payment platforms like Apple (AAPL) Pay and PayPal (PYPL) gain popularity. Earnings grew 5% to 91 cents per share on 1% revenue growth to $2.53 billion as cross-border volumes grew 16% and gross dollar volume rose 13% to $1.2 trillion on a local currency basis. Wall Street pitted No. 1 chipmaker Intel (INTC) against Apple (AAPL) chipmaker Qualcomm (QCOM) on Friday in a battle for data-center market share.The clash comes as Intel, after the close Tuesday, is expected to report roughly in-line Q3 revenue and an 11% decline in earnings per share ex items vs. the year-earlier quarter.Santa Clara, Calif.-based Intel has owned the market for chips that power data-center servers, Richard Windsor, an analyst with Edison Investment Research, wrote in a research report Friday. On Thursday, Qualcomm announced an ARM-based data-center system-on-a-chip."Over the years, server processors have consolidated in the hands of a couple of heavyweights, so competition could do the industry some good," Qualcomm wrote on its website.San Diego-based Qualcomm, with help from partners Xilinix (XLNX) and Mellanox (MLNX), could pose a threat to Intel, said Windsor. Intel sells $12 billion to $14 billion annually to data centers and enjoys 90% of the market, he said."Qualcomm is the king of execution, and if it can get a foot in the door, then there could be real trouble on the horizon for Intel," Windsor wrote.Qualcomm, though, is planning a realignment and in July announced it would cut 15% of its workforce, or some 4,700 jobs.An ARM processor in general uses less power and generates less heat than its Intel counterpart."The net result is substantially lower running costs because power is far and away the biggest operating expense of a data center," Windsor wrote.To be truly competitive, Qualcomm will need to completely rewrite its software. But that's what big ecosystems like Google (GOOG), Facebook (FB) and Apple want, he wrote."This gives them the ability to do whatever suits them in the data center," he explained.MKM analyst Ian Ing, on the other hand, sees Intel and Qualcomm as complementary. Their cooperation "increasingly makes sense," he wrote in a report.The semiconductor sphere will likely see more consolidation "with Intel potentially playing a role," Ing predicted.Intel To Report Q3Intel is expected to report an 11% decline in Q3 earnings per share vs. Q3 2014, to 59 cents, according to the consensus of 48 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Analysts expect $14.2 billion in revenue, down 2.5%.Three months ago, Intel guided for $13.8 billion to $14.8 billion in revenue.MKM's Ing forecasts an easy beat for Intel."Due to low expectations, we think results and guidance at consensus will be viewed as positive," he wrote. "Given the lack of follow-through to recent PC build activity, investors question whether Intel set a high bar with implied Q4 revenue up 4% to 5%."Intel is beating the odds of the weak PC market, he wrote."We think Intel was early to fully de-stock (its PC channel inventory) compared to broad-based semi(conductor companies)," he wrote.Also, demand remains strong in the hyper-scale cloud market, and Intel will likely focus on data centers in 2016, Ing wrote. Servers bring in about 30% of Intel's revenue, Nomura analyst Romit Shah wrote in a research note.Ing rates Intel stock a buy, with a price target of 40. Shah is neutral on Intel stock and has a 33 price target.Intel stock fell 1.2% Friday, to 32.14. Qualcomm stock rose a fraction, to 57.78.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Apple (AAPL) chip suppliers tumbled Monday on Wall Street after a German iPhone 6S chip supplier guided Q4 revenue growth down to single digits, a day before Apple is expected to report colossal earnings.Dialog Semiconductor's 20% dip in shares could also hurt its $4.6 billion attempt to acquire Silicon Valley chip gear maker Atmel (ATML). In September, Dialog valued Atmel at $10.42 per share. Now, the deal is worth 20% less.In early trading, Atmel stock dropped more than 10%.For Q4, Dialog guided to $430 million to $460 million in revenue, which would be down 1% to up 6% vs. the year-earlier quarter.Apple stock dropped more than 3% by early afternoon on the stock market today. But, the iPhone peddler's chip suppliers fell harder. Cirrus Logic (CRUS) stock took the biggest hit at 13%, ahead of the company's scheduled Q4 earnings report Wednesday.Qorvo (QRVO) stock dipped 8%. Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) stock fell nearly 6%. Shares of Avago (AVGO) and Broadcom (BRCM) — set to merge next year — were down almost 5%. Qualcomm (QCOM) stock suffered the least, down 3%.Late Tuesday, Apple is expected to report $51.1 billion in Q4 sales, up 21% vs. the year-earlier quarter, according to 50 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. The consensus also models 32% earnings growth to $1.88 earnings per share minus items.Both measures would show decceleration. Earnings have topped 40% growth for three sequential quarters. Revenue growth hasn't dipped below 25% over the same time period.Apple's December guidance is key and could dispel worries of an "iPhone 6 hangover," FBR analyst Daniel Ives wrote in a research report."We view tomorrow's earnings as a seminal event for (CEO Tim) Cook to prove the iPhone 6S skeptics wrong with a sub 70 million iPhone guide viewed as bearish," he wrote.Earlier this month, Apple chip suppliers took a severe hit upon reports that, despite then-record iPhone 6S series shipments, the smartphone giant had stepped down its Q4 intelligence-chip orders.Then, insiders said Apple would reduce its Q4 expectations to 65 million to 70 million smartphones sold.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Tough negotiations with and underreporting by Chinese smartphone makers stunted Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Qualcomm's (QCOM) fiscal Q1 guidance and, on Thursday, shares continued a drastic plunge.In early-afternoon trading in the stock market today, Qualcomm stock was down 14%, near 52, following the chipmaker's late Wednesday fiscal Q4 earnings report.For Q4, Qualcomm reported an 18% dip in sales to $5.5 billion and 91 cents earnings per share ex items, down 28% vs. the year-earlier quarter. Both measures, however, beat the consensus for $5.21 billion and 86 cents.Qualcomm guided to $5.2 billion to $6 billion in sales and 80-90 cents EPS minus items for the current quarter. Year over year, sales would be down 15% to 27% and EPS would fall 37% at the midpoint of guidance. Wall Street saw $5.79 billion and $1.08.At least four analysts lowered their price targets on Qualcomm stock on Thursday. Northland Securities, on the other hand, upped the bank's price target on Qualcomm stock to 62.50 from 60.'Refusing To Report Royalties'Rosenblatt Securities analyst Jun Zhang expressed concern that Chinese smartphone makers would continue to be a sticking point for Qualcomm's technology licensing business.Qualcomm settled litigation with the Chinese National Development and Reform Commission in February. The NRDC began investigating Qualcomm — saying it violated China's anti-monopoly law — in 2013. The resolution let Qualcomm resume licensing in China under new government-approved terms.For fiscal 2016, Qualcomm guided to $7.3 billion to $8 billion in licensing revenue, of a total $50 billion to $58 billion expected for the year.Zhang sees Chinese smartphone makers feeling pricing pressure as the market flattens in 2016."It is our view that it will be more difficult to collect royalty fees due to increasing pricing pressures on Chinese OEMs, potentially giving them the incentive to fake their number of smartphone shipments," Zhang wrote in a research report.Underreporting by some of these licensees has been a recurring theme, Qualcomm President David Aberle told analysts Wednesday during the conference call. During Q4, total reported device sales came in about $200 million below guidance "primarily as a result of the Chinese licensees I just mentioned refusing to report royalties."Tough NegotiationsDuring Q4, Qualcomm closed new licensing agreements with ZTE and TCL, two major Chinese OEMs, CEO Steven Mollenkopf told analysts during Wednesday's conference call. In 2015, Qualcomm signed 60 agreements with Chinese OEMs, Aberle said.Once new agreements are in place, the licensees will be required to make catch-up payments, Aberle said. But ongoing negotiations have been tough and long-lasting."We believe in connection with the negotiations, (some licensees) have stopped reporting certain of their sales and royalties or did not report their sales and royalties in a manner that allows us to record revenue," Aberle said.William Blair analyst Anil Doradla noted Qualcomm is, inarguably, "entering a period of uncertainty." Still, he still likes the company's capital return program that is focused on returning 75% of free cash flow to shareholders in the form of dividends.Qualcomm is also on track to cut $1.4 billion in spending as part of its restructuring program, Doradla wrote in a report.Doradla rated Qualcomm stock an outperform. Zhang reiterated a buy rating on Qualcomm stock and a price target of 65.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Apple (AAPL) supplier Avago Technologies (AVGO) might jettison its unprofitable industrial segment in lieu of a renewed focus on smartphone chips, MKM analyst Ian Ing suggests.This comes as Avago and fellow Apple chip suppliers like Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), Qorvo (QRVO), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), Qualcomm (QCOM) and Cirrus Logic (CRUS) face continued constraints from slowing growth in the iPhone market, Ing wrote."Avago is increasingly exposed to the challenges of cyclicality at both Apple and broader semiconductors," Ing wrote in a recent research report.The industry is expecting a 10%-15% decline in March-quarter iPhone sales, and a Credit Suisse analyst suggested earlier this month that Apple had cut its November orders by 10%. Shares of Apple and its suppliers tumbled on that report.Ing sees Avago as having a slim chance of guiding Q1 above the consensus when it reports its fiscal Q4 earnings after the close Dec. 2. If its guidance falls short, that would reflect hampered iPhone sales and Avago's sale of its optical module manufacturing business to China-based tech manufacturer Foxconn Interconnect Technologies, Ing wrote.He maintained his buy rating on Avago stock but dropped his price target to 158 from 159.Record-Smashing Sales, EPSFor its Q4 ended Oct. 31, Avago is expected to report a record $1.85 billion in sales, up 15% vs. the year-earlier quarter, and $2.38 earnings per share ex items, up 20%.Three months ago, Avago guided to $1.84 billion in sales, plus or minus $25 million.For the year, the consensus of 24 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters sees Avago pulling in $6.9 billion in sales and $8.84 EPS minus items, up 60% and 80%, respectively, vs. 2014 figures.Ing looks for Avago to return to aggressive M&A after it completes the Broadcom deal. In May, Avago agreed to buy Broadcom for $37 billion — the largest pure-tech merger ever until Dell and EMC (EMC) last month announced their $67 billion combination."Much of Avago's story continues to revolve around how fast it returns to large acquisitions as it de-levers post-Broadcom," Ing wrote.Rampant chip sector M&A action broke records in 2015 as expenses skyrocket and growth slows. Possibly to counteract rising costs and add new vertical markets, Avago, a fabless company, submitted a winning bid earlier this month for an idle Eugene, Ore., fabrication (chip manufacturing) plant, Ing wrote."We see this as a sign that Avago plans to have the benefits of scale and low-cost, in-sourced manufacturing as the semiconductor industry matures," he wrote.Avago is in IBD's Electronic-Semiconductor Fabless Group, where it has the fifth-highest Composite Rating of 92, out of a possible 99. The higher CR performers in the group are Integrated Device Technology (IDTI), ARM Holdings (ARMH), Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) and Inphi (IPHI).Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.
